A length of coarse indigo coloured linen printed in white with a diamond lattice alternately enclosing pommegranates and Tudor roses-- 22½ x 106in. (56 x 265cm.) ; an incomplete woolwork panel embroidered in coloured wools with naturalistic flowers and strawberries amidst strapwork and acanthus leaves-- 36 x 54in. (90 x 135cm.) ; and a collection of woolwork, machine tapestry panels and other textiles including altar frontals, 20th century (a lot)

A joined cotton panel monochrome printed in brown/black with scenes from Don Quixote including hunting wild boar with Sancho Panza, scrambling up a tree, and courting a lady on a mule-- 70 x 82in. (175 x 205cm), late 18th century

A length of ochre satin woven with a repeat design of stylised lilies in pale blue and green in "Art Nouveau" style-- 50 x 140in. (125 x 350cm.), circa 1900 ; and a collection of other satin lengths woven with floral patterns, early 20th century (a lot)

A tapestry panel woven in coloured wools with silk highlights depicting a lady in the foreground with a cavalry regiment beyond, within a verdant landscape-- 47 x 78in. (118 x 195cm.), probably 17th century, with restorations and re-workings, with modern outer frames and backing
"Bird" , a Morris and Company curtain of red woollen double cloth, woven with paired birds amongst flowers and foliage-- 50 x 82in. (125 x 205cm.), late 19th century

A joined panel of pale green silk brocaded with coloured silks and metal threads forming flask shaped cartouches with a rural scene within, bordered by a heart, arrows in a quiver, horns and other similar motifs, edged with metal braid-- 81 x 94in. (203 x 235cm.), circa 1730-40, French, backed

A hanging , the ground tamboured in silk and metal threads, embroidered with long stitch and tambourwork in floss silks with a pair of ducks flying over a lake, with iris in the fore-ground and buildings in the distance, within a frame of interlocking circles-- 50 x 36in. (125 x 90cm.), circa 1910, probably Turkish for export
A length of fine ivory satin painted with small sprigs of marigolds, convululous and poppies in a repeat pattern-- 29¼ x 68in. (73 x 170cm.), circa 1800, Chinese for export, damp damage

Four lengths of deep claret cut velvet with an elaborate fruit and flower design-- two 21 x 66in. (53 x 165cm.), two 21 x 64in. (53 x 160cm.) ; another-- 13 x 66in. (33 x 165cm.), probably Italian, late 19th century ; and a length of olive green silk moiré woven with ivory and brown stripes, the former with red and green chiné spots-- 21¾ x 52in. (54 x 130cm.), last quarter of 18th century, possibly French, all with damp damage

A grand piano cover of crimson silk damask woven with roses and peonies interspersed with acanthus leaves, the borders applied with tulips, carnations, birds, fruit and other flowers with various shields amongst scrolling foliage embroidered in coloured silks, edged with silk tassels, the embroidery 18th century, probably Italian, re-applied, the cover late 19th/early 20th century

A collection of various woolwork seat covers including a pair of seat covers with shaped backs and armpads worked with sprigs of flowers against an ecru ground, with a spray of roses at the bottom, with silk detailing, 20th century (a lot)

Two fragments of yellow and salmon pink silk woven with Christian iconography-- 13½ x 11in. (34 x 28cm.), 15th century ; a panel of crimson velvet, the border applied with a silver metal thread embroidered pommegranate design-- 27 x 33in. (68 x 83cm.), 17th/18th century? ; a chalice veil; and another panel

A long length of crimson and pale green double weave woven with stylised pommegranates worked in metal threads amongst a lattice linked with crowns in Italianate style-- 48 x 156in. (120 x 390cm.), early 20th century

A length of double-cloth woven in dark blue and apple green with thorny stemmed scrolling roses across the field woven in red and green changeant-- 50 x 112in. (125 x 280cm.), circa 1900, in the style of the "Silver Studio"

An embroidered horizontal fragment worked in crimson, yellow, ivory and blue silks with a spray of stylised roses and tuilps flanked by birds perching on other similar flowers-- 23 x 42in. (58 x 105cm.), late 17th century, Portuguese, worn, with re-workings, cut down and re-backed

A pair of Berlin woolwork shaped cartouches worked in shades of orange in cross stitch and filled with an arrangement of various flowers in coloured wools against a cream ground in petit point-- 8 x 14in. (20 x 35cm.), mid 19th century

A chalice veil of crimson velvet applied with strapwork and acanthus leaves embroidered in coloured silk and metal threads-- 22½ x 21½in. (56 x 54cm.), framed and glazed, 17th/18th century?, probably Italian

A pair of shaped panels of crimson silk embroidered in silk and metal threads with a saint and an angel with buildings behind, in a central cartouche, the borders with scrolling flowers-- 13 x 8¾in. (33 x 22cm.), framed and glazed, 18th century?, Continental, possibly maniple ends

A pair of shaped panels of light brown velvet embroidered in metal threads and silks with an angel and a kneeling saint, within a floral surround-- 12 x 8in. (30 x 20cm.), framed and glazed, early 20th century, Continental, possibly maniple ends

Three cushions covered with crimson satin embroidered in coloured floss silks with stylised anemonies, other flowers and fruit, edged with gilt braid-- two 20 x 15in. (50 x 38cm.), one 20 x 14in. (50 x 35cm.), early 20th century (3)

A pair of cushions covered with linen panels , one tamboured in coloured wools with two sprays of carnations, the other with tulips-- 18 x 11in. (45 x 28cm.) ; and another covered with a woolwork panel-- 23 x 15in. (58 x 38cm.), all 20th century (3)

A pair of tapestry covered cushions woven in coloured wools and silks with a central roundel enclosing a Biblical scene with shepherds in a mountainous landscape-- 19 x 21in. (48 x 53cm.), late 19th/early 20th century, Continental, restorations (2)

A circular cushion covered with a tapestry panel woven in coloured silks and wools depicting a wolf dressed as a shepherd watching a flock of sheep-- 25 x 26in. "STAGE of EUROPE Decr. 1812 , a printed handkerchief of rust red and ochre cotton with Sweden, Russia, Napolean, Prussia, Jerome, Confederation of the Rhine and Austria personified, surrounded by scenes from Bonaparte's career, the inscriptions also with German translations-- 29½ x 34in. (74 x 85cm.), early 19th century

A crewelwork hanging embroidered in shades of blue with sinuous branches sprouting exotic flowers and foliage-- 42 x 68in. (105 x 170cm.), late 17th/early 18th century, damage and repairs to the ground, rebacked

An unusual patchwork coverlet , the central panel of glazed roller printed cotton depicting Crystal Palace, bordered with flower heads of the same and other printed cottons and chintz, interspersed with those of plain ivory cotton, with an outer border of white cotton printed in red with cow parsley, roses and peaches-- 96 x 76in. (240 x 190cm.), third quarter of 19th century, backed
A set of eight woolwork seat covers embroidered in pink, yellow, green and ivory wools against an ecru ground with an arrangement of roses, 20th century (8)

A pair of painted silk armourial trumpet banners with five rampant lions-- 23 x 25in. (58 x 63cm.), framed and glazed ; and a joined hanging woven with gilt metal threads, embroidered in floss silks, the field with fleur de lys within a strapwork border with a helm at the bottom-- 62 x 88in. (155 x 220cm.), all 20th century (3)

An Aubusson shaped portière woven in coloured wools, the centre with an arrangement of roses spilling from a basket, the corners with musical trophies surrounded by trailing flowers, against a cream ground, surrounded by a crimson frame, the inner edge applied with fringing-- 78 x 48in. (195 x 120cm.), late 19th century, French

An embroidered firescreen panel worked in coloured silks in satin and stem stitches with French knots against a pale green ground, with a fruiting pommegranate tree with flowers entwined in the branches and a bird in one corner, in the style of William Morris & Company--21¾ x 23¼in. (55 x 59cm.), framed and glazed, circa 1900-10

A liturgical hanging with shaped valences of ivory silk damask , the centre appliqué with IHS and a pierced heart, bordered with a garland of stylised roses, the field with cornicopiae, baskets of flowers and other motifs in silks, metal threads and sequins with painted details, with the date 1758 re-applied on the back-- 70 x 82in. (175 x 205cm.), Continental, damage and restorations

A long verdure tapestry hanging woven in coloured wools with silk highlights, with a central long legged bird within a wooded landscape, framed with a border worked with tulips, roses and other flowers amongst scrolling acanthus leaves-- 62 x 110in. (155 x 275cm.), probably 17th century, possibly Flemish, restorations and re-workings, with modern outer frame and backing

A pair of long Aubusson tapestry panels woven in coloured wools and metal threads, worked with a large-scale arrangement of exotic flowers and fruit including fuchsias and vines against a russet coloured ground, within a strapwork frame-- 40 x 126in. (100 x 315cm.), early 20th century, French, slight damage and repairs

A set of window furnishings of crimson silk with satin stripes woven with baskets of fruit and cornucopiae in a shaped cartouche alternating with an elaborate urn framed within a diamond, linked by stylised foliage, all in a pale gold colour, in neo-classical style comprising two pelmets-- 48 x 148in. (120 x 370cm.) , two curtains-- 24 x 104in. (60 x 260cm.) , two curtains-- 48 x 148in. (120 x 370cm.), all lined and interlined, , four pieces-- 48 x 154in. (120 x 385cm.) , eight pieces-- 70 x 104in. (175 x 260cm.), , two pieces-- 120 x 104in. (300 x 260cm.) , two pelmet pieces-- 26 x 70in. (65 x 175cm.), all unlined, third quarter of 19th century ; a quantity of associated silk tie-backs; and a pair of curtains and pelmet similar(a lot)

A length of strawberry red velvet cut to reveal a gold lamé ground worked with stylised fruit trees-- 25¼ x 105in. (63 x 263cm.), late 19th century, Italian ; and another of pale green silk woven with oriental style figures in black velveteen shadowed with silver lamé-- 24¼ x 96½in. (61 x 241cm.), late 19th century (2)

A panel of cotton woven in shades of green in Gothic Revival style with rampant lions flanking a raised heraldic crest-- 50 x 38in. (125 x 95cm.), second half of 19th century, probably English ; a joined fragment woven in wools with pairs of owls-- 11 x 86in. (28 x 215cm.), Voysey, late 19th century ; and two other textiles similar (4)
A length of black satin woven in shades of gold and light brown with putti riding dolphins framed by acanthus leaves in Baroque style-- 21¾ x 62in. (54 x 155cm.), circa 1900, probably French

A set of window furnishings, the silver grey cotton ground printed with pale pink anemones and green foliage, comprising two pairs of curtains, one pair-- 62 x 108in. (155 x 270cm.) ; the other-- 128 x 108in. (320 x 270cm.), lined and interlined ; one draped pelmet piece-- 168in. (170cm.) long ; another-- 64in. (160cm.) long ; and four tie-backs, modern

An Aubusson sofa and four chair covers woven in coloured wools with silk details on an ivory ground within a pale green frame, the chair covers with animals including cattle, horses, dogs and goats, the sofa cover with a dog with a bone and hounds, framed with floral garlands and swagged and tasselled drapery, 19th century, French
A pair of Fortuny cotton curtains printed in blues and greens against a stone ground with fruiting vines against a lattice-- 52 x 90in. (130 x 225cm.), lined, probably 1930s (2)

Three embroidered silk gilt framed panels , the ivory satin ground embroidered in coloured silks with floral sprigs of daffodils, roses, carnations and other flowers-- the centre panel 41 x 65in. (103 x 163cm.), the side panels 21½ x 65in. (52 x 1

A drawstring knitted purse of ivory and gilt metal stripes worked with coloured floral sprigs, the top and bottom of red silk, 1820s/30s ; another, worked with narrow geometric bands embroidered in coloured beads worked with the initials "AP 1860" [indistinct] ; and four other purses, various, dating from the second quarter of the 19th century

A large joined woolwork tapestry style panel worked with two birds by a pool in the foreground, within a verdant landscape, with a pagoda and pavilions beyond, with an outer frame of stylised flowerheads-- 57 x 73½in. (143 x 184cm.), mounted, modern

A panel of crimson velvet voided to reveal a gold ground, worked with linked ogival cartouches with pairs of facing rams beneath fleur de lys within-- 25½ x 37¾in. (64 x 94cm.), framed and glazed, probably 16th century, French?, worn ; and a collection of silk and textile fragments similar, some framed and glazed (a lot)

A cap embroidered with gilt metal threads and embellished with sequins, 19th century, Continental, possibly Dutch ; another cap back panel similar-- 10½in. (26cm.) square, framed and glazed ; and a collection of silver and gold metal braid, lace and trimmings(a lot)

A Masonic sash of pale green silk faille, embroidered in silver and gilt metal threads with symbols of Freemasonry, embellished with sequins, the back with a shield inscribed Michel Ney, Maréchal de L'Empire, Dans sa séance du 23e..jour, du 9e..mois, an de la V..L..5811--8¾ x 66½in. (22 x 166cm.), framed and glazed, circa 1800??/19th century

"Charitas" , a horizontal fragment of Brussels tapestry woven in coloured wools and silks, worked with a woman and two infants, flanked by flowers and fruit in vases-- 22 x 52in. (55 x 130cm.), probably 17th century?, cut down, re-workings and restoration, re-backed

An oval picture , the ivory satin ground embroidered in coloured silks with a posy of roses, pansies and anemonies, the stalks tied with a pale blue ribbon, inscribed on the back "Mary Andrews her Work In the year 1788 Dun [sic] at Mrs Gaylers Schoole Royston"-- 14 x 17in. (35 x 43cm.), framed and glazed

A Berlin woolwork picture worked with silk highlights, depicting a young girl decorating an ass with flowers, a boy and Irish wolfhound seated before her with other dogs, a castle and loch in the distance-- 16 x 19in. (40 x 48cm.), circa 1860 ; another similar with a young mother and child-- 22¼ x 25¾in. (56 x 64cm.), mid 19th century, framed ; and another similar worked with a cottage in a mountainous landscape-- 20¾ x 18½in. (52 x 46cm.), late 19th century, all mounted (3)
A circular woolwork picture embroidered with an arrangement of lilies, anemonies and other flowers against an ivory wool ground-- 18½in. (46cm.) diameter, late 19th/early 20th century, framed
A woolwork maritime picture worked with a Royal Navy frigate under full sail, with another ship in the distance-- 18 x 25½in. (45 x 64cm.), mid 19th century

A sampler by Sarah Ann Oldham 1821 finely embroidered in coloured silks, with two central verses "My Wish" and "The Grave" worked in black silks, with alphabets above, the sides with naturalistic trailing flowers, within an elaborate double border of stylised flowers-- 22½ x 22in. (56 x 55cm.), framed and glazed

A sampler worked in brightly coloured wools and silks with the initials "IMC" and "MM" in the top corners, with a central brick house bordered with an Adam and Eve motif to one side and other spot motifs including peacocks, other birds and a lady to the other, within a border of stylised strawberries-- 18½ x 13in. (46 x 33cm.), framed and glazed, circa 1830-40

A sampler by Emma Miles 1848 finely embroidered in silks in shades of brown and green, with a central verse "Time is the only space that is given" flanked by a pair of Adam and Eve motifs, with a band of holly leaves below and spot motifs including squirrels, oak trees, a robin and butterflies, within an elaborate stylised floral border-- 15½in. (39cm.) square ; and a small embroidered picture worked with a rural scene-- 14 x 12in. (35 x 30cm.), 20th century, both framed and glazed

A small cross stitch sampler by Sarah French 1840 worked in coloured silks, with the verse "I know the lord is nigh" at the top surrounded by hearts, crowns, birds and floral spot motifs, within a stylised bud border-- 7¾ x 12in. (19 x 30cm.)

A sampler by Jane Elizabeth Hall 1825 worked in coloured silks predominantly in cross stitch, with alphabets and numerals above the verse "You whose fond Wishes...", flanked by a pair of trees, within a stylised bud border-- 13½ x 11¼in. (34 x 28cm.). framed and glazed ; and three other cross stitch samplers worked in coloured silks by Jane and Sarah Parrott, 1847 and two 1850, unframed (4)

A linen band sampler worked in fresh coloured silks mainly in cross stitch and drawn threadwork with prayers and pious verses and the name "Thomas Mead" in the centre, the lower border with a row of coronets-- 9½ x 15in. (24 x 38cm.), probably mid 18th century

A cross stitch sampler by Mary Ann Snow 1835 worked in coloured silks with a central verse "To a Friend in affliction", flanked by spot motifs with a red brick house at the bottom, within a border of naturalistic berries and stylised carnations-- 24¼ x 26¾in. (61 x 67cm.), framed and glazed

An unusual woolwork sampler by Mary & Elizabeth Tiplady, the central panel with nine squares worked with the names and various spot motifs, with an inner frame of stylised berries, the outer border tamboured with diamonds in pink, green, blue and ivory against a dark brown ground-- 25 x 24in. (63 x 60cm.), framed and glazed, first half of 19th century, possibly American

A sampler by Hannah Gray worked in red, pink, yellow and green coloured silks in cross stitch with floral and tree spot motifs bordering a verse worked in black silks, "The voice of my Beloved sounds", the lower third with "The tree of Paradise" and Adam and Eve figures, one plucking a fruit from the tree, flanked by a pair of angels blowing trumpets, within a small border of stylised strawberries-- 16 x 22in. (40 x 54cm.), framed and glazed, circa 1820-30

A Canton shawl of ivory silk with self-coloured silk embroidery of flowers and peonies in one corner, within a border of scrolling flowers, with knotted fringe-- 150cm. square ; and another stole of black silk embroidered in coloured silks in petit point with roses and violets, with a knotted fringe on three sides-- 110 x 66cm., circa 1880 (2)

A Canton shawl of black silk embroidered in brightly coloured silks with peonies amongst scrolling flowers and foliage, with knotted fringe-- 56in. (140cm.) square ; another similar; and a dress and blouse of ivory gauze painted in primary colours with floral sprays, late 1930s (3)
A Canton shawl of ivory silk embroidered in coloured silks with figures beneath pagodas, the field with scrolling peonies, with knotted fringe-- 52in. (130cm.) square
A Canton shawl of burnt orange silk embroidered in self-coloured silks with chrysanthenums and other exotic fruit and flowers, the field sprigged, with knotted fringe-- 60in. (150cm.) square

A Canton shawl of black silk embroidered in pale green silks with scrolling peonies, with knotted fringe-- 50in. (125cm.) square ; and another similar, the ivory ground embroidered in brightly coloured silks-- 60in. (150cm.) square (2)

A Canton shawl of ivory silk embroidered in red, blue, yellow, purple and green silks with a peacock displying his tail in each corner, a pheasant above, bordered with peonies, other exotic flowers and butterflies, with a similar outer frame, the central plain field forming a cross, with knotted fringe-- 62in. (155cm.) square

A Canton shawl of ivory crepe embroidered in self-coloured silks, the corners with an arrangement of peonies and ears of corn, the flower centres embellished with metal thread, the field with scrolling foliage, with knotted fringe-- 52in. (130cm.) square

A black shawl woven with gold lamé forming large roundels and alternately with large scale roses in pink, yellow and blue, with multi-coloured fringe-- 46in. (115cm.) square, 1920s ; and two Egyptian stoles (3)

A Canton shawl of ivory silk embroidered predominantly in pink, purple and orange silks with a couple flanking a pagoda in two corners, a pheasant in the other corners, the field with scrolling peonies, with knotted fringe-- 60in. (150cm.) square

A Canton shawl of ivory silk embroidered in lilac silks with pheasants and peonies in two corners and a male and female figure beside a pagoda in the other two, the field with scrolling foliage, with knotted fringe-- 64in. (160cm.) square

A shawl of black wool embroidered in coloured silks with boteh amongst scrolling foliage-- 80in. (200cm.) square ; and another of mushroom coloured wool, embroidered in coloured silks with a border of stylised foliage beneath prayer arches-- 40 x 80in. (100 x 200cm.), both modern, Indian (2)

A shawl of rust coloured wool , the borders embroidered in blue, yellow and ivory silks with scrolling boteh-- 78 x 38in. (195 x 95cm.) ; and two other shawls of mushroom coloured wool, one woven with self-coloured foliate patterns, all modern, Indian (3)
A Canton shawl of black silk embroidered in brightly coloured silks with pheasants and finches perched amongst peonies and blossom, with knotted fringe-- 44in. (110cm.) square

An "Egyptian" stole of ivory gauze worked with beaten gilt metal forming diamonds and other geometic patterns-- 26 x 91in. (65 x 228cm.) ; and a collection of shawls and stoles including a printed "Paisley" shawl with a black centre, dating from the mid 19th century (a lot)

A "Paisley" shawl woven with a large black centre, the ends woven with two pairs of facing cones within irregular lobed ogival medallions, with an outer border of small pairs of cones, with attached canvas tag 2115 Noir 59,022--60 x 130in. (150 x 325cm.), 1860s, French, fringes removed

A fragment of 'zebra' shawl woven with red, black, brown, green, yellow, ivory and blue stripes-- 80 x 48in. (200 x 120cm.), mid 19th century ; and three other 'Paisley' fragments and shawls, 1850/60s (4)

A "Paisley" shawl woven with a pale blue centre invaded by foliage, the ends with a main border and gallery of large-scale pairs of cones interspersed with a motif of stylised vegetation sprouting from vases-- 66 x 132in. (165 x 330cm.), circa 1840-5
A shawl of ivory wool and silk woven throughout with small floral roundels within a joined border of stylised flowerheads and palmettes-- 60in. (150cm.) square, early 19th century

An unusual shawl woven in silk and wool with a raspberry pink centre invaded by hanging foliage, the ends with three asymmetric cartouches woven in pale green, blue and burgundy infilled with exotic flowers and foliage, with a scrolling border of outsized flowers and fruit-- 60 x 132in. A "Paisley" shawl woven with a large pale green ogival centre invaded by foliage, the ends with scrolling foliage and vegetation forming a U-shape flanked by a pair of large pale blue feathery cones-- 60 x 122in. (150 x 305cm.), circa 1855, probably French ; and another, damaged (2)

A "Paisley" shawl with a central black cruciform medallion, the ends with two out-sized pairs of confronting cones flanking a prayer arch, within an undulating frame-- 62 x 126in. (155 x 315cm.), circa 1855-60

A "Paisley" shawl woven with a central black cruciform medallion, the ends with two opposing out-sized cones forming a U shape containing scrolling tendrils of vegetation-- 60 x 124in. A "Paisley" shawl woven with a black central stellar medallion, the borders with facing cones forming heart shapes-- 72 x 76in. (180 x 190cm.), mid 19th century

An outstanding Duché Ainè signed shawl woven à pivot in coloured wools and silks, with a halved green and ivory centre gradating to ivory and red respectively, the ends with two out-sized crossed cones, the field infilled with palm trees, ferns and other lush vegetation, signed in a central cartouche above the harlequin ends-- 64 x 146in. Artist: ACKERMANN, RUDOLPH, PUBLISHER. THE HISTORY OF THE ABBEY CHURCH OF ST. PETER'S WESTMINSTER. LONDON, 1812. 81 HAND-COLORED AQUATINT PLATES, ENGRAVED PORTRAIT AND PLAN. 2 VOLUMES, 4TO, MODERN PURPLE MOROCCO ELABORATELY GILT, G.E.; SOME OFFSETTING TO TEXT, SOME STAINING TO A FEW TEXT LEAVES. FIRST EDITION. Abbey Scenery 213; Tooley 2. (2)

ACKERMANN, RUDOLPH, publisher. The History of the Colleges of Winchester, Eton, and Westminster; with the Charter-House, the Schools of St. Paul's, Merchant Taylors, Harrow, and Rugby, and the Free-Scool of Christ's Hospital. London, 1816. 48 hand-colored aquatint plates. 4to, 19th-century red morocco gilt, g.e., some rubbing to joints and edges; minor darkening to text and plates. FIRST EDITION. Abbey Scenery 438; Tooley 3.

ALBINUS, BERNARD SIEGFRIED. Tabulae sceleti et musculorum corporis humani. Leiden, 1747. 35 engraved plates (first 11 plates with key plates). Large folio, contemporary half calf and boards, defective -- another set of 11 engraved plates and 11 key plates, dated in plate margin London, 1747-48. Large folio, contemporary half calf and boards, binding defective; plates with minor wear, dust-soiling to text. Norman 29; Garrison-Morton 399. Sold as a collection of plates, not subject to return. (2)

[ASTRONOMY]. Astrophilogeon a Game of Science and Amusement: to which is added, a short Treatise on Astronomy and Geography. London, 1828. 60 engraved cards, including 30 hand-colored constellations and 30 outline colored maps. 16mo, 60 cards and one booklet housed in contemporary morocco pull-off case. "Of the 30 constellations, 20 have their principal stars in the north declination, and 10 in south; and 12 of the 30 are signs of the zodiac. Of the 30 maps, 24 have their chief city in north latitude, and 6 in south; and 9 of the maps are countries having kingly governments."

BEATTY, A. CHESTER. The Library of A. Chester Beatty. A Descriptive Catalogue of the Western Manuscripts. Compiled by Eric George Millar. London: Privately printed by John Johnson, 1927-30. 201 plates, including 4 colored frontispieces. 2 in 4 volumes, folio, contemporary red half morocco gilt, t.e.g., others uncut, some wear to spines and edges -- FLAKE, OTTO, editor. The Guelph Treasure. The Sacred Relics of Brunswick Cathedral formerly in the Possession of the Ducal House of Brunswick-Lneburg. Frankfurt, 1930. 107 photographic plates. 4to, contemporary blue half morocco, t.e.g., light wear to spine ends and edges. LIMITED EDITION, one of 175 copies of the translation by Sylvia M. Welsh. (5)

BALZAC, HONOR DE. Works. Boston: Hardy, Pratt & Co., 1904. Numerous plates, some color. 42 volumes, 8vo, contemporary black half morocco gilt, t.e.g., others uncut, spines gilt with fleurs-de-lys, spines faded, slight wear to edges . LIMITED "COUR DE FRANCE" EDITION, number 613 of 1250 sets. (42)

DEFOE, DANIEL. Works. New York: George D. Sproul, 1905. Engraved plates in 2 states. 16 volumes, 8vo, contemporary green half morocco gilt, t.e.g., others uncut, spines faded, slight wear to joints and corners . LIMITED "HAND-MADE" EDITION, number 1 of 150 sets. (16)

DICKENS, CHARLES. Pickwick Papers. London: Chapman and Hall, 1837 -- Oliver Twist. London: Richard Bentley, 1838. 3 volumes -- Master Humphrey's Clock. London: Chapman and Hall, 1840-41. 3 volumes -- Dealings with the Firm of Dombey and Son. London: Bradbury & Evans, 1848. 2 volumes -- The Posthumous Papers of the Pickwick Club. London: Chapman and Hall, 1887. 2 volumes. Limited Edition, one of 500 sets of a total edition of 2000. Numerous engraved plates. Together 5 works in 11 volumes, various 8vo sizes, mostly old half calf, condition varies. FIRST EDITIONS in book form except as noted. (11)
DICKENS, CHARLES. Works. London: Chapman and Hall, 1879-80. Illustrated with plates. 30 volumes, 8vo, later green half morocco gilt, t.e.g., others uncut, slight wear to extremities . (30)

DICKENS, CHARLES. The Works. London and New York: Chapman & Hall, n.d. Numerous pen-and-ink and watercolor drawings of characters from the novels by Kyd and H.C. DANIELL, THOMAS and WILLIAM DANIELL. A Picturesque Voyage to India... London, 1810. 50 hand-colored plates mounted on guards. Folio, green half morocco gilt, g.e., spine faded; some light browning and staining. Abbey Travel 516; Tooley 173.

DARWIN, CHARLES. A Monograph on the Fossil Balandiae and Verrucidae. London, 1854. 2 engraved plates. 4to, disbound; title loose, with tape stains to margin -- DARWIN. [A Monograph on the Fossil Lepadidae, or Pedunculated Cirripedes of Great Britain. London, 1851-54]. 5 engraved plates. Lacks title; JONES, T. RUPERT. A Monograph of the Entomostraca of the Cretaceous Formation of England. London, 1849. 7 engraved plates; JONES. A Monograph of the Tertiary Entomostraca of England. London, 1856. 6 engraved plates. Together 3 works in one volume; 4to, old half morocco, spine gilt, t.e.g, light rubbing to joints and covers, library mark on spine and a few pages. (2)

DARWIN, CHARLES and ALFRED RUSSEL WALLACE. On the Tendency of Species to form Varieties, and on the Perpetuation of Varieties and Species by Natural Means of Selection. In: Journal of the Proceedings of the Linnean Society. Zoology. Vol. III, No. 9. London, 1859. 8vo, original pink wrappers, uncut and unopened; minor chipping to upper right corner of cover; cloth folding case. FIRST EDITION. PMM 344a; Grolier/Horblit 23a.

DE BOSSCHERE, JEAN. Group of 20 drawings, 2 colored. Together 20 plates, each approximately 210 x 185 mm. (8 x 7 in.), one inscribed "Jean de Bosschere .16," laid down, matted, minor browning and staining . A series of drawings showing the trials of the Belgians during the German occupation of World War I, presumably for an unpublished work. (20)

DELAFOSSE, JEAN CHARLES. Receuil des Fontaines, Frontispieces, Pyramides, Cartouches... Amsterdam, [circa 1770]. 2 engraved titles and 103 engraved plates. 2 volumes in one, folio, contemporary half deerskin, corners repaired, some rubbing. (2)

DENIS, LOUIS. Guide Royal ou Dictionnaire Topographique des grandes Routes de Paris aux Villes, Bourgs et Abbayes du Royaume. Paris, 1774. Hand-colored engraved folding map and numerous outline colored engraved strip maps, engraved vignettes, engraved throughout. 2 volumes, 8vo, contemporary calf, rebacked, old spine laid down. Cohen 285. (2)

DORE, GUSTAVE. Merlin Paints the Young Knight's Shield. Gouache, watercolor and ink on laid paper, signed 'G. Dore' lower right. 40.6 x 30.5 cm. (16 x 12 in.), top half of sheet wrinkled, lower third of sheet with repair tear affectin Merlin's robe , the original drawing for Plate 6 of Tennysons's 'Vivien' from his Idylls of the King , London: Moxon and Co., 1867. We are grateful to Samuel F. Clapp for his assistance in cataloguing this lot.

DUNSANY, EDWARD PLUNKETT, Lord. The Laughter of the Gods. [Dublin, 1917]. 8vo, unbound; morocco folding case. ADVANCE PROOF SHEETS of "The Laughter of the Gods," which was included in "Plays of Gods and Men," with numerous corrections in Dunsany's hand, and an ALS by A. Beavens to Dunsany referring to the page proofs.

EINSTEIN, ALBERT. Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativittstheorie. Leipzig: Johann Ambrosius Barth, 1916. 8vo, original printed wrappers, light chipping and splitting to spine; text block detached from binding. First separate printing. Offprint from Annalen der Physik, Volume 49, no. 7. Weil 80a.

EINSTEIN, ALBERT. Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativittstheorie. Leipzig: Johann Ambrosius Barth, 1916. 8vo, original printed wrappers, uncut, spine defective and with tape repairs, chipping to edges; light marginal chipping and browning, owner's ink stamp on title. First separate printing. Offprint from Annalen der Physik, Volume 49, no. 7. Weil 80a.

EINSTEIN, ALBERT. Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativittstheorie. Leipzig: Johann Ambrosius Barth, 1916. 8vo, original printed wrappers, defective; title detached. First separate printing. Offprint from Annalen der Physik, Volume 49, no. 7. Weil 80a -- Bemerkung zu dem Gesetz von Etvs. Leipzig: Barth, 1911. 8vo, original printed wrappers, lower portion of lower cover clipped, affecting text. First separate printing. Offprint from Annalen der Physik, Volume 34. Weil 38. (2)

ELLIOT, DANIEL GIRAUD. A Monograph of the Birds of Paradise. New York and Amsterdam, 1977. Profusion of reproductions. Folio, original half leather and cloth, cover and spine lettered in gilt. LIMITED EDITION, one of 250 copies, of a total edition of 500 copies. Facsimile Edition.

EULER, LEONHARD. Methodus inveniendi Lineas Curvas maximi minimiue proprietate gaudentes... Lausanne & Geneva: M. M. Bousquet & Soc., 1744. Engraved title vignette and 5 engraved folding plates. 4to, contemporary vellum, staining to upper cover; some light browning, old library stamp on title. FIRST EDITION. Norman 731; Grolier/Horblit 28; Honeyman II, 1060-62; Dibner Heralds of Science 111.

[EUMORFOPOULOS COLLECTION]. HOBSON, ROBERT LOCKHART. Catalogue of the Chinese, Corean and Persian Pottery and Porcelain. London, [1925-28]. 6 volumes. PRESENTATION COPY, inscribed by Eumorfopoulos on half title: "To Mr. Chiang Yee with kind regards & all good wishes from G. Eumorfopoulos March 1939" -- BINYON, LAURENCE. Catalogue of the Chinese Frescoes. London, [1927] -- BINYON. Catalogue of the Chinese, Corean and Siamese Paintings. London, [1928] -- YETTS, W. PERCEVAL. Catalogue of the Chinese & Corean Bronzes, Sculpture, Jades, Jewellery and Miscellaneous Objects. London, [1929-32]. 3 volumes . Together 11 volumes, folio, original half cloth, some wear to one spine, minor wear to spine ends. LIMITED EDITION, number 58 of 725 sets. (11)

[FRANCE -- MILITARY]. Album of French Bataillon Flags and Uniforms. N.p., n.d. 60 hand-colored engraved plates. 2 volumes, 4to, contemporary calf, rebacked. Captions of first 30 plates supplied in manuscript.

FRIEDELL, EGON and ALFRED POLGAR. Goethe, Groteske in zwei Bildern. Vienna: Stern, 1926. 8vo, original printed wrappers, uncut, minor foxing to covers -- MOMMSEN, THEODOR. Rmische Geschichte. Vierter Band. N.p., n.d. 8vo, original printed wrappers, spine tape repaired. (2)

GERARD, JOHN. The Herball or Generall Historie of Plantes. London: John Norton, 1597. Engraved colored portrait, colored initials at beginning and approximately 1800 woodcut illustrations, HAND-COLORED throughout. Folio, contemporary calf, rebacked; lacks ..A1 (title), Qqqq3-4, Iiii4, ..A2, A1, Hhhh8-Iiii3 (first and last leaves) repaired, some browning and offsetting throughout, occasional light dampstaining. FIRST EDITION. Henrey 154; Hunt 175 ("...important among other things for having the first illustrations of the potato..."); Nissen BBI 698; STC 11750.

GILPIN, WILLIAM. Observations...on the Mountains, and Lakes of Cumberland, and Westmoreland. 1788. 30 engraved plates. 2 volumes . See Abbey Scenery 183 (1786) -- GILPIN. Observations...on the High-Lands of Scotland. 1789. 40 engraved plates. 2 volumes . See Abbey Scenery 487 (1808) -- GILPIN. Observations...on the River Wye, and several Parts of South Wales.... 1789. 17 engraved plates. See Abbey Scenery 546 (1800) -- GILPIN. Remarks on Forest Scenery.... 1791. 32 engraved plates. 2 volumes . See Abbey Scenery 149 (1794) -- GILPIN. Essay on Prints.... 1792 -- GILPIN. Observations....on the coasts of Hampshire, Sussex, and Kent. 1804. 6 engraved plates. Abbey Scenery 150; GILPIN. Two Essays.... 1804. 4 engraved plates. -- GILPIN. Observations on...the counties of Cambridge, Norfolk, Suffolk and Essex. 1809. 20 engraved plates. Abbey Scenery 15. All London. Together 8 works in 10 volumes, 8vo, 19th-century green morocco gilt, g.e., spines faded, some wear to spine ends and edges, some offsetting of plates affecting text . (10)

GORI, ANTONIO FRANCISCO. Museum Etruscum. Florence, 1737-43. Engraved portrait and 285 (of 299) engraved plates, some folding. 3 volumes, folio, contemporary calf, rebacked, some wear to spine ends of vol. II. Brunet II:1670. Sold not subject to return. (3)

GRHAN, AMDE. La France Maritime. Paris, 1837. 2 engraved titles and 124 engraved plates. 3 volumes (of 4), contemporary half calf over marbled boards, spine decorated in gilt and blind. Fourth volume published 1842. (3)

HALES, STEPHEN. Vegetable Staticks: Or, An Account of some Statical Experiments on the Sap in Vegetables: Being an Essay towards a Natural History of Vegetation. London: W. and J. Innys and T. Woodward, 1727. 19 engraved plates. 8vo, modern calf; library stamp on 5 text leaves and one plate FIRST EDITION, Dibner 26; Grolier/Horblit 45a; Norman 970; PMM 189.

HELMHOLTZ, HERMANN VON. Die Lehre von den Tonempfindungen als Physiologische Grundlage fr die Theorie der Musik. Brunswick: Vieweg, 1863. Illustrations in text. 8vo, contemporary half morocco, spine faded, some wear to joints, spine ends and edges; library stamps on 4 leaves (3 on title), light browning to endpaper. FIRST EDITION. Norman 1044 ("Helmholtz's 'Tonempfindungen' laid the groundwork for all subsequent research in the field of audition. It contains Helmholtz's resonance theory of hearing [and] the first elaborate theory of the ear..."); Grolier/Horblit 49a; Garrison-Morton 1562; Honeyman IV,1643.

HELMHOLTZ, HERMANN VON. Handbuch der Physiologischen Optik. Leipzig, 1867. 11 engraved folding plates (one partially colored) and 213 text illustrations. 2 volumes in one, 8vo, contemporary quarter calf, edges worn, joints starting, uncut; some browning and scattered light foxing. FIRST EDITION. Garrison-Morton 1513; Grolier/Horblit 49a; Heirs of Hippocrates 1010.

HOLBEIN, HANS. Portraits of Illustrious Personages of the Court of Henry VIII, with Memoirs by Edmund Lodge. Published by John Chamberlaine. London: Bulmer, 1828. Colored engraved portraits of Holbein and his wife and 82 colored engraved portraits, several on pink paper. 4to, 19th-century red morocco elaborately gilt, g.e., some rubbing to covers; some light marginal staining. Abbey Life 205 (note).

[ILLUMINATED INITIALS]. Group of 4 leaves apparently from 2 manuscript antiphonals on vellum, 4 larger initials (80 mm. and smaller) and 10 2- line or smaller initials, some on burnished gold or blue ground, some with white penwork tracery, one smaller initial depicting a group of saints, one corner with floral decorated border, text in red and black ink, several finials in gold and color. N.p., n.d. Leaves approx. 270 x 190 mm. (10.5/8 x 7 in.) and 308 x 228 mm. (12.1/8 x 9 in.); attractively matted and framed. (2)

[ILLUMINATED INITIALS]. Group of 4 leaves apparently from the same manuscript antiphonal on vellum, possibly the collaboration of several artists, 4 large initials (185 mm. and smaller), three on blue ground, each with elaborate pictorial border (depicting various scenes with religious character, floral decorations and animals). [Tuscany, 14th-century]. Leaves approx. 475 x 350 mm., (18 x 13 in.), two initials with circular holes (patched), margins cropped, color flaking in some areas. The initials are R, S(2), and L. Sold not subject to return.

LEECH, JOHN. A volume of illustrations for Mr. Sponge's Sporting Tour . 7 drawings, one signed with initials in plate, pencil on paper. Six reproductions after the original drawings and a printed dedication page from the artist. 280 x 185 mm. (11 x 8 in.) and smaller, minor browning and staining, all laid into a red morocco gilt album, wear to spine . Illustrations include a study of gentlemen, "Mr. Sponge arrives at Laverick Wells," "Jawleyford going to the Hunt," "Jack Frosty and Charley Slapp," "Captain Guano can't get his Stirrups the right length," "Mr. and Mrs. Jobblebury at Dinner," and "Mr. Sponge and Lucy Glitters on horseback."

LEECH, JOHN. A volume of illustrations for Punch . Together 74 drawings, forty-eight signed with initals in plate, pencil and watercolor on paper. Thirty-nine reproductions from Punch after the original drawings. 195 x 224 mm., (7.7/8 x 8 in.) and smaller, minor browning and staining, all laid down into an oblong album, morocco gilt, spine detached . The illustrations include: "The Taglioni Treaty," "Fond Delusion," "Sir Hercules Fitzroy Kelley and the Farmer," "The Honeymoon," "The Boy Brougham," "Great Moral Lesson at Madame Tussaud's," and several others.

LEECH, JOHN. An Album of drawings for "Pictures of Life and Character from the Collection of Mr. Punch" . 5 drawings, pencil, four signed with initals, three with watercolor, 138 x 210 mm. (5 x 8 in.) and smaller, minor browning, with one reproduction after the drawing, all hinged into a blue morocco gilt album . Illustrations include a View of Brighton, "Rooti-Tooit - I've got her!", "Mrs. Pottles sees no reason why she shouldn't go out on the roof of her house to see the fireworks," "A Street Fight," and "An Ornament to Society" -- Leech. 3 drawings, pencil, one with white heightening, one with watercolor. 3 original reproductions from Punch after drawings. 225 x 172 mm. (8 x 7 in.) and smaller 7 in. (225 x 172 mm.) and smaller , laid down on mat, minor browning and staining; individual folding cases . Illustrations include: "Brother, Brother, We're Both in the Wrong," "The Noble Poulterers", and "Small Boys Must be Prepaid". (4)

A fan signed de Garcia , the gauze leaf painted with a winged and crowned lady sitting beside Cupid in a tree catching butterflies, with wooden sticks - 13in. (35cm.), circa 1890 - in box

A Walt Disney fan , in the form of a brise fan with a narrow red cotton mount, the sticks lacquered red and painted with Little Red Riding Hood and two pig musicians, the verso with a little girl at her dressing table - 1930s - in box

A fan , the canepin leaf painted in bright colours with figures in 18th century dress in a landcape overlooking a lake with mountains and a castle beyond, the mother of pearl sticks carved and pierced with flowers, the guardsticks with monogram MMF with coronet above - 10in. (27cm.), circa 1885 in box decorated with chromolithographs

A Chinoiserie fan , the leaf painted with three vignettes in the manner of Pillement, the verso also with chinoiserie, a lady with a bow and arrow, on an island with a chinese fisherman in the foreground and a kiosk beyond, the mother of pearl sticks carved and pierced with figures and gilt - 11in. (28cm.), circa 1760 - in blue velvet 19th century box by Vanier Chardin, 19 Rue Auber Paris, with monogram EAO on lid (one stick damaged)
An ivory brise fan , carved and pierced with figures - 6in. (7cm.), circa 1820 ; and two other brise fans (3)

Hotel Miramar, Habana, Cuba , a chromolithographic advertising fan in tones of blue, with a couple watching a steam yacht wearing Cuban colours, and other shipping with the fort outside Havana beyond, the verso inscribed Francolin, Gilet & Cie, Paris, the wooden sticks painted white and gilt - 8in. (22cm.), circa 1910
A fan signed L. Billet , the silk leaf painted with a maid showing an apron full of flowers to two ladies, the mother of pearl sticks pierced and gilt - 11in. (27cm.), circa 1890 - in Duvelleroy box

A lithographic fan , with bone sticks and mother of pearl guardsticks decorated with cut-steel plaques - 8in. (22cm.), mid-19th century - in later fan box by A. L. Serra, Madrid, inscribed Princess Alice
A fan signed G. Lasellaz , painted with lovers in an arbour, with gauze insertions painted with flowers and edged with sequins, the mother of pearl sticks gilt - 11in. (28cm.), circa 1890
Swiss Regional Costume , a carved and wooden brise fan painted with eighteen oval vignettes, the verso inscribed with the names of the Cantons - 9in. (23cm.), circa 1870
A lace fan worked with the arms of a Continental Duke, with tortoiseshell sticks - 11in.(27cm.), circa 1870 - in box by Voisin (lacks monograms on guardsticks)
Paris International Exhibition 1867 , a wooden brise fan with a chromolithographic view of the exhibition by Aug. Klein, for C. de Leans ? Wien - 9in. (23cm.), Vienna, 1867

A fan signed C[ecile] Cheneviere , the leaf painted with a lady and Cupid, the verso with trophies of love, the blonde sticks gilt with trophies of love, the upper guardstick set with a mother of pearl Cupid - 9in. (24cm.), circa 1890 - in Duvelleroy, London box, with a pamphlet, The Secret of Charm, by Mrs. Leonard Marshall, published by Duvelleroy
A lace fan , and three other fans (4)
A fan , the leaf painted with musicians, with mother of pearl sticks - circa 1860 ; and an 18th century fan (2)
Two ostrich feather fans , one pink, one red; two Chinese feather handscreens; two other fans; and two purses (8)

A fan , the leaf painted with figures in a landscape with a river and a church beyond, the ivory sticks carved and pierced - 12in. (29cm.), English with Chinese guardsticks, circa 1740 - in 19th century fan box

The Judgement of Paris , a printed fan, the leaf a hand-coloured etching, the ivory sticks carved and pierced - 11in. (28cm.), English, mid-18th century - in box ; a pierced brise fan painted with two figures - circa 1820 ; and the ivory sticks of a Cantonese fan carved with monogram H.M. and with mountains and a pagoda (3)

1796 Leap Year Fan , a printed Almanack fan, the leaf engraved on both sides with oval stipple engraved landscape vignettes for each month with seasonal birds, with description and verse beneath, published Janry 1. 1796 by J. Cock & J.P. Crowder, Wood St., engraved by S.J. Neele, 352 Strand, with Duty Stamp, with wooden sticks - 11in. (27cm.), English, 1796

Chemins de Fer de L'Ouest , a chromolithographic fan signed E. Nerme, with circular views of Trouville, Dinard, Dieppe, Dinan Chateau de Combourg and Mont St.Michel, the verso with advertisements for Villerville Plage, Compagnie Generale Transatlantique, Grand Hotel Terminus, Gare St. Lazare, etc. and on the guardsticks Biere de St. Germain, Cirier, Pavard & Cie, published by A. Clarey, Lemenil & Nerme, 21 Rue de'Hauteville, Paris, and Asnieres, Seine, with wooden sticks - 13in. (32cm.), 1893
Fete Henry Monnier 1er Juin 1904, signed with monogram HM [Henri Mirande] a chromolithographic fan of a caricature of a girl stuck in tree - 10in. (25cm.), 1904
Fete Henri Monnier signed Cheret , Reprod.aut. Imp Chaix, with a chromolithograph of clown sitting at a table, with wooden sticks - 10in. (24cm.), 1904
Fete Henry Monnier, signed with monogram A.R.[Auguste Roubille] , a chromolithographic fan with a lady and putti, with wooden sticks - 10in.(24cm.), 1904
A rare French Royalist fan , the silk leaf applique in spangles Vive Le Roi and with fleurs de lys, the bone sticks stained red - 7in. (17cm.), circa 1814

Christ and the Woman of Samaria , a painted fan with ivory sticks - 10in.(26cm.), Dutch, circa 1780 ; and a fan, the silk leaf applied with a stipple engraving printed in colour,the reserves embroidered with sequins, the verso painted with three sprays of tulips and other flowers. the bone sticks pierced and gilt - 10in.(26cm.), circa 1785 (2)
A tortoiseshell brise fan ; a lithographic fan; a folding parasol with ivory handle; and another fan (4)

LYSONS, Daniel. The Environs of London , London: A. Strahan, 1792-96, 4 volumes, 4°, FIRST EDITION, 4 engraved titles, 3 maps, 61 engraved plates, 3 of them coloured and 2 folding, 3 letterpress tables (some browning and offsetting onto text, vol. IV heavily dampstained at end), contemporary calf (worn, lacking two lower covers). [Upcott p. 914] (4)

MIDDIMAN, Samuel. Select Views of Great Britian , London: S. Middiman, [n.d.] [plates dated 1784-92], oblong 4°, engraved title and 48 plates only (of 53, mainly marginal spotting), contemporary half calf (worn), bookplates of Mary Addington and Henry William Hoskins.

MOSS, William George. The History and Antiquities of the town and port of Hastings, London: W. G. Moss, 1824, folding engraved plan and 19 engraved plates, prospectus for the work bound in at front (occasional spotting), contemporary paper-backed boards (lightly rubbed), printed spine label. With another book. (2)

PAPWORTH, John B. Select Views of London; with historical and descriptive sketches of some of the most interesting of its Public Buildings , London: R. Ackermann, 1816, 8°, 76 hand-coloured aquatint or engraved plates, mid 19th-century speckled calf (extremities rubbed, rebacked preserving old spine), g.e. [Abbey Scenery 217; Tooley 361]

ROSS, Frederick. The Ruined Abbeys of Britain , London: William Mackenzie, [n.d.], 2 volumes, 4°, half titles, coloured wood-engraved frontispieces and 10 plates after A. F. Lydon, wood-engraved illustrations (occasional light spotting), original pictorial cloth gilt, g.e. (2)

SANDBY, Paul. A Collection of Landscapes drawn by ... , London: 1777, oblong 4°, 32 engraved plates (tear at margin of one plate, another with neat repair at inner corner, some worming at margin of first 7 leaves), contemporary calf (rebacked with old spine relaid, new lower cover) -- Clarkson STANFIELD. Stanfield's Coast Scenery: a Series of Views in the British Channel , London: 1836, 8°, engraved frontispiece, title and 38 plates (plates browned), modern half morocco -- Peter SANDBY. The Virtuosi's Museum containing select views in England, Scotland and Ireland , London: 1778, oblong 4°, engraved title and 108 plates after Sandby (lacking descriptive text for plates 35, 94 and 99, plates 94 and 99 misbound, minor spotting and offsetting), contemporary mottled calf (restored, new endpapers). (3)

SHEPHERD, Thomas Hosmer & James ELMES. Metropolitan Improvements; or, London in the Nineteenth Century, London: Jones & Co., 1827, 4°, additional engraved title, map of Regent's Park and 163 views on 81 sheets (occasional light spotting, map and a few captions cropped), contemporary morocco (rubbed), g.e. With London Interiors: a Grand National Exhibition (2 vols., London, 1841). (3)

SHEPHERD, Thomas E. London in the Nineteenth Century illustrated by a series of views, London: Jones & Co., 1829, 4°, engraved title and 97 engraved views on 40 sheets (occasional light spotting), contemporary cloth-backed boards (lightly rubbed) -- The Continental Tourist, Belgium & Nassau, London: Black and Armstrong, [n.d.], 8°, additional engraved title and 53 engraved plates (some light browning), original cloth decorated in gilt and blind (lightly rubbed, joints split), g.e. With 15 other books, most of British topographical interest, also including Mortimer Menpes' The Durbar (limited edition, London, 1903). (17)

WILLIS, Nathaniel Parker and Joseph Stirling COYNE. The Scenery and Antiquities of Ireland , London: George Virtue, [1841], 2 volumes, 4°, portrait frontispiece, engraved title, map and 118 plates by W. H. Bartlett (spotting and browning), contemporary polished calf gilt (lightly rubbed), g.e. (2)

ALVARES, Francisco. Historiale Description de l'Ethiopie, Antwerp: Christopher Plantin, 1558, small 8°, woodcut plans in text (lacking c 6-d 2 and one of 3 blanks at end, H 2 - 3 and v3 torn with loss, several clean tears, title browned and stained), contemporary calf (restored). [Sorgeloos 6; Voet 53A]

[AVRIL, Philippe] Voyage en divers Etats d' Europe et d' Asie, Paris: chez Jean Boudot, 1693, 12°, additional engraved title and 8 plates, contemporary speckled calf (rebacked). With Louis Daniel Le Comte's Nouveaux Memoires sur l'Etat Present de la Chine (3rd edition, 2 vols., Amsterdam, 1698) and Gui Tachard's Second Voyage ... par le Roy au Royaume de Siam (Paris, 1689, lacking the plates). (4)
BARROS, Joao de. L'Asia, Venice: Appresso Vincenzo Valgrisio,

BELL, John. Travels from St. Petersburg in Russia, to diverse parts of Asia, London [i.e. (?) Edinburgh]: for W. Homer, 1764, 2 volumes, 8°, folding engraved map (cleanly torn, occasional light spotting), contemporary calf gilt (extremities rubbed, spine labels worn). [ESTC notes that the imprint is false] -- Jean Baptise Barthélemy Baron de LESSEPS. [ Journal historique . English] Travels in Kamtschatka, London: for J. Johnson, 1790, 2 volumes, 8°, FIRST ENGLISH EDITION, folding engraved map (map and some text leaves stained, occasional light spotting), modern morocco-backed cloth, Merton House stamps on titles. With one other book on Russian travel. (5)

CHOISY, Franois Timoleon de. Journal du Voyage de Siam ... nouvelle édition, Trevoux: par la Compagnie, 1741, 8°, contemporary calf, spine gilt in compartments (lightly rubbed). With Louis André de la Mamye de Clairac's Histoire de Perse (3 vols., Paris, 1750), and another work in 2 volumes. (6)

A Collection of Voyages undertaken by the Dutch East-India Company, for the improvement of trade and navigation. Containing an account of several attempts to find out the North-East Passage, and their discoveries in the East-Indies, and the South Seas, London: for W. Freeman [and others], 1703, 8°, FIRST ENGLISH EDITION, 10 engraved maps, most folding, contemporary panelled calf (upper joint split, slight surface worming to lower cover). [Sabin 14401]

COXE, William. Account of the Russian Discoveries between Asia and America. To which are added, the Conquest of Siberia, and the history of the transactions and commerce between Russia and China, London: for J. Nichols, 1787, 8°, third edition, 5 folding engraved maps and plates (2 plates cleanly torn, light spotting), contemporary calf (rebacked and rubbed). [Howes C834; Sabin 17309]

DALRYMPLE, Alexander. Voyages dans la Mer du Sud ... traduit de l' Anglois ... par M. de Fréville, Paris: Saillant & Nyon, 1774, 8°, FIRST EDITION IN FRENCH, half title, 3 folding engraved maps (one cleanly torn at fold, half title and title lightly stained at margin), contemporary calf (lightly rubbed and stained, upper joint split, a few minor repairs). [Sabin 18344]

DU HALDE, Jean Baptiste. The General History of China ... the second edition corrected, translated by Richard Brookes, London: by and for John Watts, 1739, 4 volumes, 8°, 4 folding engraved maps and 19 plates, many folding (a few short, clean tears to maps, occasional spotting and staining), contemporary speckled calf (rebacked, lightly rubbed) -- Gabriel de MAGALHAES. A New History of China, translated by John Ogilby, London: for Thomas Newborough, 1688, 8°, FIRST EDITION IN ENGLISH, folding engraved plan of "Pekim" (pen trials to title, occasional light spotting and staining), modern calf. [Wing M247] With a third book on China. (6)

ERCILLA Y ZUNIGA, Alonso de. La Araucana, Madrid: D. Antonio de Sancha, 1776, 2 volumes, 8°, engraved portrait, folding map of Chile and 3 plates (occasional light browning), contemporary calf, spines gilt (lightly rubbed). [Palau 80425: "Bella edición"; Sabin 22725: "'the best edition'"] (2)

FERNANDEZ DE OVIEDO Y VALDES, Gonzalo. Historia General y Natural de las Indias, Islas y Tierra-firme del Mar Océono, Madrid: Imprenta de la Real Academia de la Historia, 1851-55, 4 volumes, 4°, 15 lithographed plates (occasional light spotting and browning), contemporary calf-backed boards (worn). [Palau 89532:"Edición magnifica en todos los conceptos, tanto por el mérito histórico y literario como por la presentación nitida y correcta"; Sabin 57990] With Martin Fernandez de Navarrete's Coleccion de los Viages y Descubrimientos, que hicieron por mar los Españoles desde fines del siglo XV (5 vols., Madrid, 1825-37, vols. IV and V in facsimile) and Gaspar Correa's Lendas da India (4 vols., Lisbon, 1856-64). With 5 others. The lot sold not subject to return. (18)

HERMITE, Jacques L'. Journael van de Nassausche Vloot ofte Beschrijvingh van de Voyagie om den gantschen Aert-Kloot, Gedaen met elf Schepen, Amsterdam: Joost Hartgertsz, 1648, 4°, wood-engraved title vignette, folding engraved plate (plate wormed, cropped with slight loss and repaired, title and first few leaves wormed and repaired, occasional staining), early 20th-century decorated boards (lightly rubbed). [Sabin 31505]

IDES, Evert Ysbrants. [ Driejaarige reize naar China . English] Three Years Travels from Moscow over-land to China ... to which is annex'd an accurate description of China, done originally by a Chinese author, London: for W. Freeman, J. Walthoe [and others], 1706, 4°, FIRST ENGLISH EDITION, engraved title dated 1705 used as a frontispiece, large folding engraved map and 30 plates, 8 folding (short tear at fold of map, small rust-holes in 2 plates and a few text leaves, one plate cropped, another rubbed with slight loss of engraved surface), modern calf. [Lust 519]

JUAN Y SANTACILLA, Jorge & Antonio de ULLOA. A Voyage to South America, London: John Stockdale [and others], 1806, 2 volumes, 8°, fourth edition, 7 folding engraved plates and plans (occasional light browning and spotting), contemporary calf (rebacked, rubbed). [Sabin 36813] With John Mawe's Voyages dans l' Intérieur du Brésil (2 vols., Paris, 1816), and one other work. (5)

LERY, Jean de. Historia Navigationis in Brasiliam quae et America dicitur, Geneva: Eustathius Vignon, 1596, 8°, later edition, 6 full-page woodcut illustrations (lacking folding plate which is supplied in facsimile, a few leaves very lightly stained), contemporary vellum (a few small stains). [Adams L536; cf. Sabin 40153 (1586 edition)]

LOZANO, Pedro. [ Individual y verdadera relacion de la extrema ruyna que pedeciò la Ciudad de los Reyes Lima . English] A True and Particular Relation of the Dreadful Earthquake which happen'd at Lima, London: for T. Osborne, 1748, 8°, second edition, 9 folding engraved maps and plates (a few repairs, lightly browned and spotted), modern half calf, stamp of the New York Historical Society on title. [Sabin 42693] With Guillaume Joseph le Gentil de la Galaisiere's Nouveau Voyage ... enrichi de plusieurs plans, vues & perspectives des principales Villes & Ports du Pérou, Chily, Bresil, & de la Chine (3 vols. in 2, Amsterdam, 1708). (3)

MARTINEZ DE ZUNIGA, Joaquin. An Historical View of the Philippine Islands, translated by John Maver, London: for J. Asperne [and others], 1814, 2 volumes, 8°, half titles, folding engraved map (map torn, occasional spotting), contemporary half calf gilt (lightly rubbed). With Bartolome Leonardo y Argensola's Histoire de la Conquête des Isles Moluques (3 vols., Amsterdam, 1707), George Keate's An Account of the Pelew Islands (4th edition, London, 1789), Alexis Marie de Rochon's A Voyage to Madagascar (London, 1793), and one other work. (8)

MENDES PINTO, Fernando. The Voyages and Adventures of ... during his Travels for the space of one and twenty years in the Kingdoms of Ethiopia, China, Tartaria, Cauchinchina, Calaminham, Siam, Pegu, Japan, and a great part of the East Indies ... done into English by H.C., London: by J. Macock for Henry Herringman, 1663, 2°, third issue (rust hole in Gg4 not affecting text, mainly marginal browning and spotting, a few stains and heavier spot marks), contemporary calf (rebacked, worn). [Wing M1706A]

EINSTEIN, ALBERT. Five typed letters signed ("A. Einstein") to Frantisek Navara in German, one letter with three-line autograph postscript, Nassau Point, Peconic, Long Island, N.Y., 3-28 August 1938. Together 5 pages, 4to, minor browning (especially to the letter of 22 August), not affecting legibility .

EINSTEIN, ALBERT. Photograph signed ("A. Einstein 1946"), also signed by the photographer, Paula Wright, and dated 1946. 346 x 265mm. 13.5/8 x 106 in.), neatly matted. A fine portrait, printed by Wright, a New York photographer, depicting Einstein standing in front of a clapboard house (at Princeton University?)., holding a large notebook under his arm, his pipe in his hands, looking off-camera, his white hair in sharp contrast to the dark background. Signed in ink on the cover of the notebook he carries.

EINSTEIN, ALBERT. Typed letter signed ("A.Einstein") to Roy Wood Seltara, Princeton, (N.J.), 15 February 1946. 1 page, 4to, return address embossed at head of sheet, with original envelope. Einstein responds regarding a scientific theory proposed by his correspondent. : "I have studied your manuscript and to a certain extent grasped your problem. You are trying to manage without the continuum and to develop the whole of physics 'out of matter', as the fundamental concept. I am convinced that physics cannot accomplish that. With other words: 'realism' is possible, 'materialism' is not. I regret to lack the time to give you the reasons here; I should find it desirable to discuss the problems with you ... if the occasion could be found ..."

EINSTEIN, ALBERT. Typed letter signed ("A. Einstein"), to the physicist Robert S. Shankland, Chairman of the Physics Dept., Case Institute of Technology, Princeton, 29 October 1952. 1 page, 4to, embossed stationery . "Dear Dr. Shankland, your resume does not correspond exactly with the thoughts I was endeavouring to express. I am sending you therefore something what [ sic ] I could have said on the occasion..." -- EINSTEIN. Typed statement DESCRIBING THE INFLUENCE OF MICHELSON AND OTHER PHYSICISTS ON THE ORIGIN OF THE THEORY OF RELATIVITY. [Princeton, 29 October 1952]. 1 full page, 4to, embossed stationery . -- EINSTEIN. Autograph scientific diagram relating to Michelson's experiment, the top portion (statistics) in Shankland's hand, n.p., 25 May 1921 (according to Shankland's pencilled note), 1 page, in pencil . With a copy of Shankland's letter of 27 October 1952. Together three items .

EINSTEIN, ALBERT. Typed letter signed ("A. Einstein") to the physicist Robert S. Shankland, Department of Physics, Case Institute of Technology; Princeton, N.J., 17 September 1953. 1 full page, 4to, on Institute for Advanced Study stationery.
EINSTEIN, ALBERT. Typed letter signed ("A. Einstein") to the physicist Robert S. Shankland, Princeton, N.J., 31 August 1954. 1 full page, 4to, on Institute for Advanced Study stationery.

[ENGLAND, SOVEREIGNS]. CHARLES I, King of England . Letter signed ("Charles R") as King of England, to Lord Viscount Falkland, Deputy General of Ireland, and others, Westminster, 27 June [1627/28]. 1 page, folio, text in a small, neat, scribal hand. CREATING AN IRISH BARONETCY. The King informs Falkland that "...Sir John Taaffe of Ballymote in the County of Sligo...a principall gentleman of an eminent English family and well assented[?] to our service," whose father, Sir William Taaffe, had "long served in the warres of that kingdom with much valour and reputation...we have thought...to advance him now to the honour and titles of a Baron and a Viscount of that our realm..." Falkland is commanded to draw up the patent "under the greate seal of our realm," making him "Lord Baron of Ballymote and Viscount Taafe of Corrin..." -- CROMWELL, OLIVER, Lord Protector . Document signed ("Oliver P.") as Lord Protector of Great Britain, Whitehall [London], 19 April 1655. 1 page, folio, text in an attractive italic hand, verso with endorsement signed by LISLEBONE, LONG, Speaker of the House of Commons, boldly signed by Cromwell at top. Cromwell, Lord Protector since 1653, issues an official order of payment to Lislebone Long "for so muche of his Salary due to him...for his attendance about Our person." Together two items. (2)

[ENGLAND, SOVEREIGNS]. HENRY VII. Letter signed ("Henry R") to Rychard Bruse, Kenilworth Castle, n.y. [c.1500?], 1 page, oblong, defective along right-hand edge with loss of several words, repaired from verso, slight spotting , a formal letter thanking Bruse for his support and favors in the past and recommending the bearer, Wyot [Wyatt?]. and praying that he be given credence. Rare. -- CHARLES II. Letter signed ("Charles R") to Sir John Laurence, Lord Mayor of London; Whitehall, 14 November 1664, 1 page, folio, integral blank, Good letter regarding a complaint brought by Sackville Whittle "one of our Chirurgiens in ordinary," whose "apprentice Henry Wingfield, who hath served him Foure years in the Trade and Mystery of a Chirurgeon...is endeavouring to withdraw himself from his said Master's service..." Laurence is specially asked to look into the case, so that "Servants may not be encouraged to leave their Masters upon slight Grounds..." -- JAMES II. Autograph note signed ("JR"), to "Mon Cusin le Duc de Lausun", n.p., n.d. page, 4to, integral address leaf, in French: "La Reyne et moy avions oblie de demander a voir les Estanderts et Drapeaux quands nous fumer a Marli, quoy que nous avions l'intention de la faire, je ne scay si le Roy ne voudroit pas nous les envoyer pour les voir un moment, devant qu'on les envoy a Paris..." -- WILLIAM III. Document signed ("William R") to "The Commissioners of our Treasury," Kensington, 4 March 1695, 1 page, folio, invisibly silked, written in an elegant chancery script, countersigned by Sir Stephen Fox John Smith and Charles Montagu (later Earl of Halifax), authorizing payment of 300 to Thomas Pelham "to be by hym applied for the clearing and benefit of our Harbour at Newhaven..." -- MARY II. Document signed ("Mary R") Viscount Sydney, Lt. General and Governor of Ireland and others, Whitehall, 27 September 1692, 1 page, folio, integral address leaf, in a fine chancery hand, regarding estimated costs "for fitting up the Parliamen t House in that our Kingdom," which costs are not to exceed 620.12s.5p, countersigned by Stephen Fox and Charles Montagu -- ANNE I. Document signed ("Anne R"), St. James Palace, [London], 21 January 1703, 1 page, oblong folio, minor discoloration, ON PARCHMENT, papered wax seal, countersigned by Nottingham, an appointment of James Otway to the rank of Captain "of a Troop in the Regiment of Horse commanded by...Bragadier Daniel Harvey..." Together 6 items. (6)
EUCLID (fl. ca. 300 B.C.). Elementa geometriae . Translated from the Arabic by Adelard of Bath. Edited by Giovanni Campano. Venice: Erhard Ratdolt, 25 May 1482.

[EUROPE, POLITICAL and MILITARY FIGURES]. A group of approximately 100 items, including autograph letters signed, letters signed, typed letters signed, documents signed, and cut signatures. V.p., v.d. Various sizes, condition varies .

[EUROPE, SOVEREIGNS AND ROYALTY]. A group of approx. 45 items, including autograph letters signed, letters signed, documents signed, cut signatures and seals by the ruling families of Europe. V.p., v.d. Various sizes, conditon varies .

FERDINAND V, and ISABELLA I, King and Queen of Spain . Letter signed ("Yo el rey," and "Yo la reina," each with large paraph), to the President and Judges of the Town of Vallid; Madrid, 25 February 1495. 1 page, folio, 305 x 216 mm. (12 x 8 in.), tipped to a larger sheet , in Spanish. Text in a slightly flourished Spanish court hand, attestation of scribe Juan de la Parra "por mandado de la Rey e la Reina," at bottom. Fine condition.

[FRANCE, SOVEREIGNS]. CHARLES IX. Letter signed ("Charles") to FRANOIS PAVIE, BARON DE FOURQUEVAUX, Ambassador to Spain (1509-1574), Chateau de Boullongue, 29 July 1568, 3 full pages, folio, address panel on page 4, fine condition, in French, A REVEALING POLITICAL LETTER WRITTEN JUST BEFORE THE THIRD WAR OF RELIGION., clearly defining his policy of using armed force to subdue the Protestants and speculating on Philip II's military plans (the Netherlands were in open revolt against Spanish rule). To his Ambassador, the King describes the defeat of the Protestant army under Coqueville by the Marchal de Coss in Picardy, and expresses the hope that this disaster will inspire fear in those who unite to defy his edict. The "punishments [torture] inflicted upon the prisoners will be a warning to others," and it should be made widely known that all rebels will be similarly treated. "After having carefully considered the best way...of keeping each one to his duty, it seemed to me, and I am well advised, that it must be accomplished by force, which...will serve to chastize and punish those who violate my wishes and also to prevent such calamities from falling upon us again, especially since those who have suffered most in the past troubles have been my poor people. I have decided that for their relief, the best things was to seek help from a well-paid police force; these will maintain the garrisons and will be able to care for the poor people..." He has sent the Marechal de Vielleville against the citadel of La Rochelle and the discusses at length the military plans of Philip II. -- MEDICI, CATHERINE DE (1519-1589), Mother of Charles IX . Letter signed ("Caterine") to Guy Chabot, Baron de Jarnac, Governor of La Rochelle and Mayor of Bordeaux. Paris, 16 August 1567. 1 page, folio, in French. PROTESTANT VERSUS CATHOLIC Interesting letter written during the Second War of Religion, regarding the Protestant stronghold of La Rochelle. Catherine writes that the Protestants there "have been under suspicion that they have been fooled," and asks that Chabot "make a tour as far as La Rochelle, to reassure them and make them cease their defiance. As for the outcry that...they like to make, they will vanish, being full of sound and fury and it will be necessary for those who are so agitated by such slight reasons to calm themselves and be wise..." Together two items. The Wars of Religion--a virtual Civil war between Catholics and Huguenots--raged from 1562 on, relieved by uneasy truces and culminating in 1572 in the Massacre of St. Bartholomew, authorized by Charles (1550-1574) who had been from an early age under the almost complete domination of his mother Catherine, consort of Henry II. Diplomatic letters of such significant content are unusual. Fourquevaux, an experienced diplomat and soldier, had been appointed ambassador to the Spanish court in 1565 and served there until his death. (2)

FRANCE, SOVEREIGNS]. A good collection of significant monarchs: FRANOIS I. Letter signed ("Francoys") to the Duke of Milan, St. Germain, February 20, [after May 1526]. 1 page, folio, in French. Excellent diplomatic content, probably regarding the League of Cognac (established in 1526 between Franois, the Pope, Venice and Sforza against Charles V and Spain)., mentioning "shipments which I have made" in observance of "the league made between us," and noting that the Pope has applied himself to cooperating and mediating any troubles which might arise: "By cessation of arms, by truce, one makes peace with one's enemies. I beg you, my cousin, to continue on the same course, and be sure that for the continuance of your state we shall do no less than we would be willing to do for our own..." -- CHARLES VIII. Letter signed ("Charles") TO LODOVICO SFORZA, Duke of Milan ("Il Moro"), [Paris], 4 August 1495. 1 page, 4to , in French. Requesting the Duke grant his protection and assistance to the bearer, Jehan de Bulloigne, "mon valet du chambre," who is passing through Milan to Ferrara for the purpose of escorting back to France the wife of the King's Seneschal Guido Paganino -- FRANOIS II. Document signed ("Francoys"), Chinon, 10 May 1560. 1 page, oblong folio . ON PARCHMENT, in French. Ordering his Treasurer of War to pay a soldier and an archer each their wages, although they were absent from roll call, "seeing they were at the time occupied elsewhere." -- LOUIS XIII. Autograph letter signed ("Louis"), to "Le Chancellor," Perrone, 5 July 1642. 1 page, 4to, in French. Stating that he has "willingly granted clemency to a woman imprisoned at Tours"-- HENRY II. Document signed ("Henry"), Amboise, April 1551. 1 page, large folio , ON PARCHMENT, text in an attractive scribal hand, very boldly signed, in French. Concerning Francisqua Villa, and rewards for his services to the King's father (Franois I) -- HENRY II. Letter signed ("Henry") to Raymond de Beccarie de Pavie, Baron Fourquevaulx, Master of the Pantry, Camp at Trelon, 15 July 1552. Requesting he attend the King "immediately" in order to find out his anticipated movements during the military campaign against Lorraine (March-July of this year). Rare in letter form. -- LOUIS XII. Document signed ("Louis"), Lyons, 18 May 1503. 1 page, oblong 4to , ON PARCHMENT, in French. Ordering payment to Michel Beleynes "for a trip he made by coach last summer past, from Honfleur...to the Duchy of Milan to warn us" of the arrest of M. Helart "who has been exonerated" of charges he carried letters from the English King -- LOUIS XI. Document signed ("Louys"), Plessis du Parc, 14 September 1478. 1 page, oblong 4to, minor stains , ON PARCHMENT, in French. Lengthy order regarding a clerk of Dijon and his problems with banditry in the area of Burgundy under his authority, for which he is granted special compensation -- LOUIS XVIII. Autograph letter signed ("Louis") to an unidentified correspondent, Verona, 25 August 1795. 1 page, 8vo , in French. Due to the resignation of the Duke of Polignac, the King "could choose no one more worthy than you to carry out so important a mission...I direct you to...proceed directly to Vienna, where you will find my instructions and further orders..." -- HENRY IV. Document signed (Henry"), Paris, 1607. 1 page, oblong folio, ON PARCHMENT, with intact papered seal, in French. An elaborate payment order in favor of the Duke de Tovare. -- LOUIS XVI. Partly printed document signed ("Payez Louis"), Versailles, 1 November 1774. 1 page, oblong 4to, torn along left hand edge, cropped at top , ordering payment to a widow "for subsistence" -- LOUIS XIV. Letter signed (Louis") to M. Daguisseau, St. Cloud, 19 April 1678. 1 page, large folio, boldly signed, in French. Instructions that Isaac Ranchin of Montpellier, a soldier in the horse musketeers and a convert from the Protestant faith, be paid a pension by his father -- Together 12 items . (13)

[FRANCE, SOVEREIGNS]. NAPOLEON I, Emperor of France . Letter signed ("Nap") as Emperor, to Prince Eugne de Beauharnais, Viceroy of Italy (1781-1824), Paris, 23 December 1810. 1/2 page, 4to, in French. Napoleon writes his stepson (Josephine's son by her first husband), his aide-de-camp in the Austrian campaign (1809): "My son, I have heard of a report of the Minister of External Affairs highly critical of the conduct of Moreau. my Consul at Ancona...for this reason he should be discharged..." -- LOUIS XV, King of France . Letter signed ("Louis") to Karl Albrecht, Elector of Bavaria (CHARLES VII, Holy Roman Emperor), Versailles, 15 April 1727. 1 page, WITH INTACT RED WAX SEAL, in French. LOUIS XV TO THE FUTURE CHARLES VII, claimant of the Austrian throne. Royal congratulations on "the great joy you felt at the birth of a son, which your wife the electress has just given birth to...Be assured that on all occasions I shall proceed to demonstrate the special affection I have for you, by contributing in every way I can to your good and that of your household...I pray God that he keeps you in his holy and worshipful protection..."' A leaf from the second impression of the Mainz Catholicon, printed ca. 1469, possibly from two-line castings preserved from the original impression of 1460. Three distinct impressions of the Catholicon have been identified. The present leaf contains the Galliziani watermark (the family emblem of the Galliziani brothers, papermakers of Basel) indicative of the second impression. CLEMENS, SAMUEL LANGHORNE ("Mark Twain"). Autograph letter signed ("Saml. L. Clemens") TO THE SHOWMAN, PHINEAS T. BARNUM ("My Dear Barnum"), Hartford, Connecticut, 19 Febraury [1874]. 1 pages, 8vo, on pages 1 and 3 of a four-page sheet, Clemens' "SLC" monogram on page 1, blank lower portion of second leaf cut away. "A PERFECT FEAST OF QUEER LITERATURE." Apparently the earliest recorded letter of the author to Barnum, recording Clemens' enthusiastic reaction to read of the unsolicited letters received by the showman: "It is an admirable lot of letters. Headless mice, four-legged hens, human-handed sacred bulls, 'professional Gypsies,' ditto 'Sacasians,' deformed human beings anxious to trade on their horrors, school-teachers who can't spell,--it is a perfect feast of queer literature! Again I beseech you, don't burn a single specimen, but remember that all are wanted & possess value in the eyes of your friend Saml. L. Clemens."

CLEMENS, S. L. Autograph letter signed ("Mark Twain") to the Editor of the World (retained copy), n.p. [Hartford?], n.d. [ca. 25 November 1917]. 1 page, large 8vo, neatly tipped to a larger sheet . MARK TWAIN, DISGRUNTLED INVESTOR: A satirical Thanksgiving squib, on the failure of an investment trust in which Twain lost money.: "You ask me for a sentiment which shall state how much I have to be thankful for, this time. For years it has been a rule, with me, not to expose my gratitude in print on Thanksgiving Day, but I wish to break the rule, now, & pour out my thankfulness, for there is more of it than I can contain without straining myself. I am thankful--thankful beyond words--that I had only fifty one thousand dollars on deposit in the Knickerbocker Trust, instead of a million; for it I had had a million, in that bucket shop, I should be nineteen times as sorry as I am now, Trusting that this pean of joy will satisfy your requirement..." -- CLEMENS. Typed letter signed ("M.T. (S.L. Clemens)") to the President and Directors of the Knickerbocker Trust Co., n.p. [New York], n.d. ca.17 January 1917], 1 page, 4to, on pale blue paper. : "I expect nothing out of you--at least--nothing but your disapproval of me for publishing the above [the preceding]...Instead of putting your hands in your pockets and paying your debts...you have been shilly-shallying...trying to escape your obligations...Do you suppose any one will risk money with you again? Next time you will bring up in jail, where you probably ought to have been many and many a year ago. At large, you are a common danger, whereas in jail you could be useful--useful as an example. Also happy, for you would be at home; at home, and among sympathetics; sympathetics, and all harmonious, wearing the same handsome stripes. Oh! you must not think of resuming, it would make the people to laugh, as the French say...They would remember that the government and the capitalists hastened to rescue the Lincoln and the other reputable trusts, but hadn't a kind word for you...Affectionately..." (2)

Autograph manuscript signed of the story "The Mystery of Marmaduke [Extracted from the Diary of the Reverend Noah Kilminster, of Cauld Kirk, North Britain], " n.p., 1878 (pencilled note from Collins to the printer at head of first page dated 23 November 1878). 19 pages, 4to., (pages 8 and 9 cut down to smaller size by Collins), written in dark brown ink on rectos only of sheets of tannish paper (a few sheets in fragile condition): page 1 separated along 3 horizontal old folds with loss of several lines at bottom, pages 2,3,4, 17 and 18 all with a few word losses due to burn holes from acidic ink (especially where Collins has crossed out portions of text), last few lines on p.18 (end of Postscript) apparently lacking; titled and signed ("Wilkie Collins") at head, a working manuscript with extensive revisions (heavy deletions and interlinear and marginal additions) by Collins, paginated at top, with numerous editorial blue pencil markings and directions .
