GARRICK, DAVID (1717-1779), actor . Autograph letter, signed ("D. Garrick") to Thomas Racket (an Oxford undergraduate), Adelphi Theater [London], 2 December 1775. 3 pages, 4to, 226 x 184 mm. (9 x 7 in.), integral address leaf in Garrick's hand, small red wax seal with initials "DG" . "I PLAYED HAMLET LAST WEDNESDAY." A cheery letter to a young admirer. In 1770, Rackett, aged fourteen, had recited Garrick's ode for the Shakespeare jubilee and so impressed him that Garrick gave the boy a presentation copy of the work. The following year, Garrick gave Rackett a folio copy of Shakespeare with a laudatory inscription. Here, Garrick thanks Rackett for a "noble" Christmas present: "I shall have no occasion to trouble my Butcher or poulterer any more...I played Hamlet last Wedenesday & after the play your Father and Mother went home with us to take part of my Chicken...Hamlet was ye most crowded house we ever had & Archer was a more splendid one tho' not quite so profitable..."

LONDON, JACK. Seven typed letters signed, one typed leter (stamped signature), one typed note signed, and one autograph note signed (all "Jack London,") to Spiro D. Orfans in San Francisco; written from Glen Ellen, California, and Honolulu, 21 December 1910-19 October 1916. Together 10 letters and notes, 16 pages, 8vo and 4to (mostly), double-spaced, five of the letters professionally de-acidified and encapsulated in mylar (the encapsulation process reversable) . [ With :] 11 letters and 1 card from Jack London's wife Charmian to Orfans, 1913-1938; 7 letters (some carbons) from Orfans to Jack London, 24 February-18 November 1916, and 5 autograph letters signed (some retained drafts?) from Orfans to Charmian, 1916-1917; a photograph of Jack London and Charmian, inscribed and signed by Charmian to Orfans and signed by London, all on verso, 77 x 105 mm., mylar encapsulated ; 9 photographs of London, London and Charmian, London and Orfans fencing, London's valet,etc., 12mo-8vo, a few with wear and creases ; 6 vintage picture postcards of London and/or the Glen Ellen ranch and 3 modern pictorial postcards of same; 12 photographs of Orfans and his family; a newspaper clipping, 1917, about Orfans; and a group of letters, etc., from Peter Orfans (Spiro's son) explaining his view of the nature of the London-Orfans relationship, and a few letters from scholars, etc., regarding this archive. Virtually all of the items are in a half green morocco and cloth quarto-size binder . THE DARKER SIDE OF LONDON An important correspondence revealing a troublesome side of Jack London: his attitude towards race and his capacity for mean-spirited bullying. Spiro D. Orfans (1886-1948) was a Greek immigrant who became an artist when he moved to the West Coast in 1908. He wrote to London and received an invitation to visit him at Glen Ellen. He became friends with London and his wife Charmian, and often stayed at the ranch, fencing with the writer and joining in various activities. In his five letters and notes to Orfans dating from 21 December 1910 to 13 December 1914, London invites Orfans up to the ranch, gives him advice on "clear thinking" (Orfans had a "predisposition towards metaphysics"), talks of events at the ranch (Charmian writes him about the devastating fire at their new home, Wolf House, in August 1913), and tells him of his travel and other plans. During this period Orfans virtually became a London acolyte. The dispute, reflected in London's five letters of 1916, began after Orfans wrote London in November and December 1915 questioning the writer's racial views (e.g., the superiority of the Anglo-Saxon race) expressed in The Mutiny of the Elsinore (1914). London responded in his letter of 25 January 1916, unleashing a verbal attack on Orfans: "...you say that my main proposition of race in The Mutiny of the Elsinore is not quite clear to you. Next, you want me to tell you all about it. Nobody asks anybody to bow before anybody. Either they bow or they do not bow. They are made to bow, or they cannot be made to bow. God abhors a mongrel. In nature there is no place for a mixed breed..." London gives several examples of the mongrelization of pure breeds, and continues: "There's no use in your talking to me about the Greeks. There are not any Greeks. You are not a Greek. The Greeks died two thousand years ago, when they became mongrelized...The Greeks were strong as long as they remained pure...when they mongrelized themselves by breeding with the slush of conquered races, they faded away, and have playing nothing but a despicable part ever since in the world's history. This is true of the Romans; this is true of the Chaldeans; this is true of the Egyptians; this is not true of the Gypsies, who have kept themselves pure. This is not true of the Chinese, it is not true of the Japanese, this is not true of the Germans, this is not true of the Anglo-Saxons. This is not true of the Yaquis of Mexico. It is true of the fifteen million mongrels of Mexico; it is true of the mongrels that inhabit the greater portion of the West Indies, and who inhabit South America and Central America from Cape Horn to the Rio Grande...Read up your history. You will find it all on the shelves. And find me one race that has retained its power of civilization, culture, and creativeness, after it mongrelized itself..." 22 March 1916 (in response to Orfans' letter of 24 February): "...You prove that you are not a clear thinker, you prove that you have no homogeniety of blood in you, you prove that you have a base hetereogenity of blood in you when you treat me the way you do...You make a noise...as though you talked science. You don't know the first word of science...No man can be scientific and personal at the same time...What you are is not a Greek, ethnologically considered. The Greeks died over two thousand years ago..." London then comments on Orfans' attitude towards him: "You who come along, fawning and lick-spittling at my feet, kissing my hand, saying that you are a disciple of my great God-Almightiness of intellect, and have read all that I have written and swallowed it whole, and assert that I am the most magnificent and wonderful human-thinking creature that ever came down the pike -- you do all this, as you have done from my first contacts with you, and then, because you have happened to have read one of my latest novels, proceed to get in and worry me, and challenge me, and ding-dong at me, for me to tell you what I really meant in said latest novel, and I finally patiently come through and tell you what every written word of mine has uttered from the first book I ever published. Read "The Son of the Wolf" short-story, in my very first book, entitled The Son of the Wolf [1900]. Read the dedication in that book. Find there that I laid down the very principle that I have ever continued to lay down..." (The dedication London refers to reads: "To the sons of the wolf who sought their heritage and left their bones among the shadows of the circle.") London continues his attack: "...Because you are a boob, because you are the stupid thing that you are, because only at this late date you learn what my printed stuff has always stood for, you come back and call me a quack and a hypocrite, and a thrower of bull. In reality you crucify yourself upon your own colossal stupidity -- the cross is the stuff you have ever read and have never grasped...What do I care that the paramount reason why you do not make love to another man's wife is, not because it is against one of the Commandments, but because you couldn't look that man in the eye and tell him to go to hell if you felt like it. You silly slush! Let me give you a tip: After you have successfully loved and possessed another man's wife is the very time you can look that man in the eye and tell him to go to hell." London devotes a paragraph to Lord Byron in Greece, and closes: "...Well, you claim you are a glorious Greek. How have you treated this white man me?...I have given you much. You sought me out...At the end of it all you have behaved toward me as any alleged modern Greek peddlar has behaved toward the superior races he has contacted with anywhere all over the world. You weak, spineless thing. One thing remains to you. Get down on your hams and eat out of my hand. Or cease forever from my existence..." As the heated debate between the two grew, Orfans demanded that London send him a bill for his room and board when he was a guest for several weeks. They settled on a $60 charge; they then argued whether it had been paid or not. In London's last letter, of 19 October 1916, written a month before his death, he encloses a duplicate of the missing letter/receipt and comments: "...Now you are trying to pull it over by denying that you ever received the letter. This is a stereotyped habit of mongrels. Mongrels are always subterranean...In your case, when I see you repeatedly using the one favorite phrase of vituperation on your list, namely 'you chunk of bluff,' I can only conclude that you are continually advertising your own weakness. This weakness is bluff...Please remember that only a mongrel can mistake vituperage for logic. Please remember, Spiro, that you have to sleep by yourself, and that it is up to you to decide, when you run over your entire affair with me, from beginning to end, whether you are a good fellow with which to sleep." On Orfans' last letter to London, dated 18 November 1916 -- London died at his Glen Ellen ranch on 22 November -- he has written a note many years after: "S.F. Jan. 24th. 1937. As I read this letter over twenty one years later I regret that Jack died three [sic: four] days later. He was a fine man although a little oversure of himself when he dealt with a 'lesser mortal' like me...now I feel and always did that it was better if he had lived and I lost forty such arguments with my right hand to boot." Apparently this London-Orfans archive is the only extant two-way correspondence of London's: it is certainly the only known controversy in his letters. (10)

(8 x 56 in.), the blank side neatly backed, closely written, in German. With an ALS of Wolfgang Heine, 19 October 1916, 4 pp., 12mo, regarding Marx's letter.

MELVILLE, HERMAN. Autograph letter signed ("H. Melville") TO JULIAN HAWTHORNE (author and son of Nathaniel Hawthorne), [New York], 10 August 1883. 2 pages, 8vo, in gray-blue ink on the rectos of two leaves (separated at center fold and rehinged with clear tape, touching, but not covering, a few letters), tipped to larger sheet .

MILLAY, EDNA ST. VINCENT. The Ballad of the Harp-Weaver . New York: Frank Shay, 1922. Small square 8vo. Original plain tan wrappers, stapled, within original printed red wrappers with vignette on front (a corner on front tan wrapper bit chipped, some slight edge wear to red wrappers); orange half morocco slipcase. FIRST EDITION., ONE OF FIVE COPIES PRINTED ON JAPAN VELLUM. PRESENTATION COPY, inscribed by Millay on half-title to the musician and book-collector Efrem Zimbalist: "To Efrem with very great love Edna." Inscribed by the publisher Shay on front tan wrapper: "One of five copies printed on Japan Paper, Frank Shay." Frontispiece and vignettes. The first trade edition of The Ballad of the Harp-Weaver consisted of 500 copies (all printed on regular paper); all but 75 of these were bound in orange wrappers identical to the red wrappers noted above; for window display in his Greenwich Village shop Shay had the 75 copies bound (15 each) in five different colored wrappers: red, dark green, apple green, yellow, and blue. "Simultaneously with the first edition there were printed five copies on Japan vellum, having the same title-page as the regular edition, but differing from the regular edition in that the endsheets were omitted... The only one I have seen was bound in red wrappers. Mr. Shay has no record or recollection of what other colors were used on these five copies" -- Yost 15. A FINE COPY AND OF EXTREME RARITY: there was no Japan vellum copy in the personal Millay collection of John S. Van E. Kohn.

MILLAY, EDNA ST. VINCENT. Renascence and Other Poems . New York: Mitchell Kennerley, 1917. Small 8vo. Original cream paper-vellum boards, gilt-lettered, uncut (some slight rubbing); orange cloth slipcase. FIRST EDITION of the author's first book, COPY NUMBER 13 OF 17 NUMBERED COPIES PRINTED ON JAPAN VELLUM SIGNED BY MILLAY and in this binding. INSCRIBED BY HER opposite title-page to the musician and book-collector Efrem Zimbalist: "To Efrem Zimbalist From Edna St. Vincent Millay, Harbor Head, September 7, 1931." With Kennerley's "compliments" slip laid in. Although the limitation notice states that 15 copies were printed on Japan vellum, 17 were actually done. A very good copy of one of the great first-book rarities of modern American literature. Yost 3.

POE, EDGAR ALLAN. AUTOGRAPH LETTER SIGNED ("E A POE") TO THE NEW YORK PUBLISHERS J. AND H.G. LANGLEY, [PHILADELPHIA, N.D.], POSTMARKED 18 JULY [1842]. 1 PAGE, SMALL 4TO, WRITTEN IN BROWN INK, ADDRESSED BY POE ON VERSO, WITH POSTMARKS AND A DOCKET ON VERSO, TIPPED TO QUARTO SHEET., SLIGHT MARGINAL SOILING AND NICKING, A SMALL MARGINAL SEAL TEAR, REMNANT OF RED SEALING WAX, A LITTLE CREASED .

STEINBECK, JOHN. Autograph letter signed ("John Steinbeck") to W.G. Erne, book representative for the Los Angeles News Company, Los Gatos, California, n.d., envelope postmarked 29 June 1938. 1 page, 4to, a trifle wrinkled, with the original stamped envelope addressed by Steinbeck and the recipient's letter to the author .

STEINBECK, JOHN. Typed letter signed ("John") to Dennis Murphy, Sag Harbor, New York, 26 May 1956. 2 pages, 4to, single-spaced, on three sheets of onion-skin paper with Steinbeck's name and address imprinted at head of the first page, more than 1800 words, a few pencilled corrections by the author, some slight marginal foxing .

STEINBECK, JOHN. Autograph letter signed ("John S.") to Dennis Murphy, n.p. [probably Sag Harbor], 9 July [1956]. 3 pages, folio, in light blue ink on two sheets of lined white legal-pad sheets, some light staining, slight rubbing along folds; with typed transcript .

STEINBECK, JOHN. Autograph letter signed ("John") to Dennis Murphy, Beverly Hills, 1 September 1956. 2 pages, small folio, in blue ink on both sides of a sheet of Beverly Wilshire stationery, several dampstains (not affecting legibility); with typed transcript .

STEINBECK, JOHN. Autograph letter signed ("J.S.") to Dennis Murphy, n.p. [Sag Harbor], 21 September 1956. 1 page, folio, in blue ink on lined yellow legal-pad sheet, a few light stains, a bit rubbed at a folds; with typed transcript .

STEINBECK, JOHN. Autograph letter signed ("John") to Dennis Murphy, n.p. [New York], 16 December 1957. 4 pages, folio, in pencil on two lined yellow legal-pad sheets, some slight soiling; with typed transcript .

STEINBECK, JOHN. Autograph letter signed ("John") to Dennis Murphy, Discove Cottage, Bruton, Somerset, England, 29 March 1959. 4 pages, 4to, in blue ink on four sheets of thin paper, Steinbeck's address embossed at head of first page, with a few slight, mostly marginal stains; with original addressed envelope and with typed transcript .

STEINBECK, JOHN. Autograph letter signed ("John") to Dennis Murphy, n.p. [Discove Cottage, Bruton, Somerset], "I guess this must be about July 15" [1959]. 3 pages, folio, in blue ink on two lined white legal-pad sheets (each with two punch-holes in left margin), some light staining and fold rubbing, skilfull repairs to small fold holes (with loss of a few letters) and slight marginal tears; with typed transcript, and with a photocopy of a 1969 letter from Elaine Steinbeck to Murphy on the death of John Steinbeck.

WHEATLEY, PHILLIS. Autograph manuscript of the 70-line dramatic poem, "Ocean," n.p., n.d. [ca. September 1773]. 3.1/8 pages, 4to, 223 x 183mm. (8 x 7 in.)., small ink stain at extreme lower edge, page 4 bearing the concluding two lines of verse and a docket in a contemporary hand: "Ocean A poem by Phillis in her handwriting made on her return from England in Capt. Calo. Sept. 1773."

WHITMAN, WALT. Leaves of Grass . Boston: James R. Osgood & Co., 1881-1882. 8 o, original publisher's mustard-yellow cloth, gilt-stamped signature of Walt Whitman on upper cover, gilt-blocked spine. (shaken, several quires loosening, spine discolored, front-free endleaf slightly loose at top and bottom, dampstain to lower corners of early leaves and portrait facing p.29. Half dark brown morocco slipcase. Seventh edition. Wells & Goldsmith, pp.24-25.

WOLFE, THOMAS. Typed letter signed ("Thomas Wolfe") to Miss Dorothea Hettinger, New York, 21 May 1933. 1 page, 4to, single-spaced, boldly signed by Wolfe in pencil, usual fold creases, with original stamped envelope .

ADAMS, JOHN, President . Manuscript document signed ("John Adams") as President, countersigned by Secretary of State Timothy Pickering, Philadelphia, 29 August 1798. 1 page, oblong, 284 x 435 mm. (11 3/16 x 17 3/16 in.), large papered Great Seal of the United States at lower left, attractive calligraphic heading "John Adams, President of the United States of America." Very fine. An appointment for Elijah Brigham as Commissioner for Massachusetts under the Act of Congress "to provide for the valuation of lands and dwelling houses and the enumeration of slaves within the United States."

ADAMS, JOHN, President . Autograph letter signed ("John Adams") to Aaron Hobart, Quincy, [Mass.], 25 December 1823. page, 4to, integral address leaf in Adams' hand. ADAMS EXPRESSES APPROVAL OF THE FAMOUS MESSAGE WHICH DEFINED THE MONROE DOCTRINE.: "I am under great obligation to you for the President's [Monroe's] message, & for the Document of the War & Navy Office and am proud to see how ably and faithfully the Government is conducted & these communications are the more acceptable as coming from a grandson of my beloved brother..."

ADAMS, JOHN QUINCY, President . Autograph letter signed ("J.Q. Adams") to Joseph Blunt, Washington, D.C., 27 November 1832. 1 full page, 4to, 253 x 203 mm. (9.15/16 x 8 in.), integral blank tipped to a larger sheet. Fine.

ADAMS, JOHN QUINCY, President . Autograph letter signed ("J.Q.Adams") to Aaron Hobart, Washington D.C., 15 March 1836. 1 full page, 4to. ATTACKS BY HIS OPPONENTS: Adams has heard of attacks on him circulated "by the Senatorial frank into my district," in "Revenge for my Resolutions." It was unfortunate for Mr. Webster that...he hurried the Senate...into a desparate quarrel with the House...upon principles utterly untenable, and so unpatriotic that they are sinking him and the Senate...They must fall. They do their worst to demolish me...I stand beyond their reach as far as the principles upon which I have acted..." -- ADAMS. Letter signed ("John Quincy Adams") as Sec. of State to Hobart, 20 January 1821. 1 page, 4to. Forwarding "the Journal of the Federal Convention."

ADAMS, JOHN QUINCY, President . Autograph letter signed ("J. Q Adams") to Aaron Hobart, Washington, D.C., 3 May 1836, 4 pages, 4to, brittle at edges with some chips and small repairs (tape) at margins, clean horizontal separation to first leaf.

Opera selectiora quae Titianus Vecellius Cadubriensis et Paulus Calliari Veronensis inventarunt ac pinxerunt , [n.p]: 1682, 2°, engraved title and 28 plates on 24 sheets only (one plate mounted to rear paste-down, two small holes neatly repaired on two plates, some light soiling), contemporary calf (worn, covers detached). [Cicognara 3390].

LE FEBRE, Valentine. Opera selectiora quae Titianus Vecellius Cadubriensis et Paulus Calliari Veronensis inventarunt ac pinxerunt , [n.p]: 1682, 2°, engraved title and 25 plates (all mounted), contemporary half calf (worn).

Locomotives for narrow gauge railways, manufactured by Sharp, Stewart & Co., Limited, Atlas Works, Glasgow, Scotland , [Glasgow]: Atlas Works, [n.d], 4°, 24 mounted photographic plates (heavily browned), original cloth (head and tail of spine frayed).

[MALCOLM, John] Sketches of Persia, from the journals of a traveller in the East, London: John Murray, 1828, 2 volumes, 8°, "new edition" (occasional light spotting), contemporary cloth-backed boards, printed paper spine labels, modern slipcase. (2)

MARTIN, Robert Montgomery. The British Colonies; their History, Extent, Condition, and Resources, London: London Printing and Publishing Company, [ca. 1855], 6 volumes, 4°, additional engraved title, 39 double-page engraved maps, hand-coloured in outline, 30 portraits and 9 plates (occasional light spotting and marginal staining), contemporary half calf (extremities rubbed). (6)

MORIER, James. A Journey through Persia, Armenia, and Asia Minor, to Constantinople, in the Years 1808 and 1809, London: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown, 1812, 4°, FIRST EDITION, 3 folding engraved maps and 26 plates, most aquatints (one map torn without loss, occasional light browning and spotting), contemporary half calf gilt (heavily rubbed). [Abbey Travel 357]

PALLADIO, Andrea. The Architecture of A. Palladio in four books. A short Treatise of the Five Orders, and the most necessary Observations concerning all Sorts of Building ... revis'd, design'd, and Publish'd by Giacomo Leoni ... translated from the Italian original , London: by John Darby for the author, 1721, 2 volumes in one, 2°, second edition, engraved frontispiece, portrait and 204 plates only (of 215, spotted and browned), modern brown half morocco gilt. [Fowler 224].

PORCACCHI, Thomaso. Funerali antiche de diversi popoli, et nationi , Venice: Simon Galignani, 1574, 4°, FIRST EDITION, engraved title and 24 illustrations (light spotting and browning), contemporary calf (joints split but cords still holding). [Brunet IV. 820; Cicognara 1766; Summers p. 466].

[RAILWAYS ETC.] An album of approximately 46 loose watercolour and pen and ink studies of locomotives, average size 110 x 170mm., mid-19th-century. With a quantity of journals and sketch books including "Sketches in Sussex 1814", "Views Around Beachy Head 1814" and "Journal to the Lakes &c." dated 1811, most bound in calf. (a lot)
SEUTTER, Matthaeus. Belgradum sive Alba Græca, [Augsburg: ca. 1740], hand-coloured engraved plan, panoramic view of Belgrade (a few spot marks), 492 x 570mm.

STUART, James & Nicholas REVETT. The Antiquities of Athens measured and dilineated, London: John Haberkorn, 1762, volume one only (of 4), 2°, 71 engraved plates (a few plates very lightly spotted), contemporary calf (rather worn).
VAENIUS, Otto. Batavorum cum Romanis bellum... , Antwerp: 1612, oblong 8°, 36 engraved plates (slightly soiled and browned), contemporary half calf (rubbed), t.e.g.

VENEGAS, Miguel. A Natural and Civil History of California ... translated from the original Spanish, London: for James Rivington and James Fletcher, 1759, 2 volumes, 8°, FIRST EDITION IN ENGLISH, folding engraved map and 4 plates (map torn without loss, small hole in H7 of volume one not affecting letters, occasional light staining and spotting), modern cloth gilt, slipcase. [Cowan p. 658; Howes V69; Sabin 98845] With Jean Chappe d'Auteroche's A Voyage to California (London, 1778, severely wormed). (3)

WHEELER, George M. & A. A. HUMPHREYS. Report upon United States Geographical Surveys west of the one hundredth meridian ... Vol. IV. Botany, Washington: Government Printing Office, 1878, 4°, coloured lithographed frontispiece and 30 lithographed plates, original cloth gilt (worn), bookplate and signature of Howard Willis Preston and with engraved presentation label of George M. Wheeler. With 3 others of related interest including Charles S. Sargent's Report on the Forests of North America (Washington, 1884). (4)

DARWIN, Charles. The Descent of Man, and Selection in Relation to Sex , London: John Murray, 1871, 2 volumes, 8°, FIRST EDITION, FIRST ISSUE, illustrations, original green cloth (binding of volume one detached). [Freeman 245] -- James A. MONCRIEFF. The Scientific Structure of The Universe with maps of the Great Globe of Heaven, with its Four Star Temples , London: Marcus Ward, 1880, 8°, FIRST EDITION, PRESENTATION COPY, front endpaper with inscription "Thomas Carlisle [sic] Esq with the author's compliments", maps, some coloured, original cloth (lacking cloth backstrip to spine), bookplate of Thomas Carlyle. (3)

DIETRICH, David. Zeitschrift fuer Gaertner, Botaniker und Blumenfreunde , Jena: August Schmid, 1840-43, volumes I-II only, small 4°, 109 hand-coloured engraved plates (slightly browned, some soiling), contemporary half calf (worn). [Pritzel 2270] (2)

FABRIZZI, Girolamo. Opera Anatomica , Padua: Antonio Meglietti, 1625, 4 parts in one volume, 2°, 42 engraved plates, including 11 double-page (lacking final leaf of index to the last part, one plate cleanly torn and repaired, small hole in plates 19 and 28, light dampstaining and offsetting), contemporary vellum (small section of lower cover worn away, light staining). [Krivatsy 3804]

HALFORD, Frederic M. Modern Development of the Dry Fly, London: George Routledge, [1910], 8°, photogravure frontispiece and 43 plates, some coloured (one detached, occasional light spotting), original cloth gilt (lightly stained). With 2 other works in 6 volumes including F. Edward Hulme's Familiar Garden Flowers (3 vols., London, n.d.) bound in green morocco. (7)

MORRIS, Francis Orpen. A History of British Butterflies , London: George Routledge, 1904, 8°, ninth edition, 79 hand-coloured plates (occasional light spotting), original cloth (slightly stained, spine faded). With F. Edward Hulme's Butterflies and Moths of the Country Side (London, [n.d.]). (2)

SCOTT, Peter. Morning Flight, London: Country Life, [1935], 4°, limited to 750 copies signed by the artist, 16 mounted coloured plates by Peter Scott, illustrations, original cloth gilt (lightly soiled and rubbed).

SOWERBY, James and James Edward SMITH. English Botany, or Coloured Figures of British Plants, London: for the author, 1790-1810, volumes I - XXX only (of 36), 8°, 2,232 engraved plates, almost all hand-coloured, 2 folding, early pencil annotation at margins of many plates (occasional spotting and staining, mostly light and marginal, a few plates cropped not affecting image, a few small holes in text leaves, lacking leaf of text for plate 1228 in volume XVIII but with duplicate description for plate 1225), contemporary tree calf (rather worn, lacking most spine labels). Artist: BANNER OF THE JEWISH LEGION VETERANS, ca. 1918. A blue velvet banner, 132 x 86 cm., embellished with yellow and gold bands, metallic threads and silver sequins. The arched words "Jewish Legion Veterans" (also in Hebrew) and "E.E.F. Palestine" surround a large Star of David in the banner's lower half; "Royal Fusiliers" flanks the star. At top, a menorah stands upon a banner carrying the word "Kadimah" in Hebrew; at bottom are the dates "1915-1918." -- A green velvet Torah mantle (72 x 42 cm.) embroidered in colored and metallic threads. Commissioned in 1931 in memory of Yisrael David bar Ya'akov Tempelhoff, whose name appears in the large Star of David that adorns the mantle's center. -- A linen Torah Binder (15.6 x 163 cm.), of which two [of four] pieces remain, embroidered in multi-colored threads of greens, browns, yellows, purple, etc. Its Hebrew inscription now reads: "Shelomo, son of Yehudah Strauss, born under a good sign, the 13th of Adar, [5]550 [1790]." A bird-like head forms the ascender of a lamed , an acorn and a foliate branch surmount additional letters. At bottom right is embroidered the child's nickname, "Zalo." (3)
A George III style mahogany bookcase. 88 1/2 in. high, 65 1/2 in. wide, 30 in. deep.
A George III style mahogany bookcase. 88 in. high, 57 3/4 in. wide, 30 in. deep.

ABOAB DE FONSECA, ISAAC. Parafrasis comentado sobre el Pentateuco [Paraphrase, or commented Spanish translation of the Pentateuch]. [Amsterdam:] Jacob de Cordova, 5441 [1681]. Engraved title by Johan van den Avele, representing Abraham, Moses and David and three episodes from the life of Isaac, an allusion to the author's first name. Folio, modern calf gilt; title mounted, 3C1, 3O1, 4C1, 5F2 all torn, browning . Wolf I, 1140, IV, 18; Rodr.Castro, 487, 590; Rib.Santos, 300; Kayserling, 4; Palau, 891; Den Boer, Catalogue [...] Ets Haim/Livraria Montezinos , n. 8.

ABRAHAM BEN CHIYA. [Hebrew] Sphaera mundi...Arithmetica secundum omnes species suas autore. Rabbi Elija [Mizrahi]. Basle: Heinricus Petri, 1546. 2 parts in one volume, 4to, bound in a fragment of a thirteenth-century scholastic legal manuscript on vellum, joints wormed, extending to catch last four leaves of text . Editio princeps of part I, Hebrew and Latin text, general title in red and black, full-page woodcut of a sphere on verso of title to part I, numerous astronomical woodcut diagrams in text, historiated initials, device at end of each part, with the blanks b2 part I and *4 part II. Adams A-33; Houzeau & Lancaster 1217; Prijs 75; Zedner, p. 15.

ABRAHAM BEN SOLOMON OF HAMBURG. Aleh Terufah [Responsa. Part I: Treatise of the legal permissibility of vaccination (for smallpox); part II: notes on tractate Berakhot; part III: Sermons given in the London Beth ha-Midrash of the Ashkenazim]. London: Alexander ben Judah and his son Judah Leib ben Alexander, 1785. Title within simple typographical border. 3 parts in one volume . Vinograd, London 111; Roth, London 52; Roth, Magna p. 338: 18; Zedner 28; not in Cowley; Roest 37 -- SOLOMON IBN MELEKH OF FEZ. Mikhlal Yofi im Leket Shikhechah [Grammatical work, edited by Jacob Abendana'. Amsterdam: David de Castro, Tartas, 1684. Folio, contemporary vellum, first title detached, Latin title stained, last leaf torn and defective, some slight waterstaining. Vinograd, Amsterdam 508; Fuks 482; Zedner 729; Cowley 660; Roest 1013 -- NIETO, DAVID BEN PHINEHAS. Matteh Dan ve-Kuzari: Chelek Sheni [polemical work; defense of the oral law]. London: Thomas Ilive, 1714. 118 leaves, 2 leaves "Dedicatoria" in Spanish, 3 leaves Hakdamah in Hebrew + 1 leaf title, text otherwise in Hebrew. 4to, contemporary vellum. Vinograd, London 25; Roth, London 5; see Zedner 614; Cowley 153; see Roest 905. Matteh Dan is the most important work of David Nieto (1654-1728), the Haham of the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue in London. In it Nieto opposes the opinion of those former Marranos to whom the Rabbinic law was unacceptable -- BUZAGLO, SHALOM BEN MOSES. Sefer Hadrat Melekh [first part of his commentary on the Zohar]. Amsterdam: Gerard Johan Janson for Israel Mondovi, 1766. Title within typographical border, 8vo, contemporary calf, rubbed . Vinograd, Amsterdam 1893; Zedner 163; Roest 248; Scholem, Bibliographia kabbalistica, No. 16, p. 190 -- BUZAGLO. Sefer Hadrat Melekh; Perush Idra; Kevod Melekh; Hod Melekh; Penei Melekh [five treatises on the Zohar]. London: n.p., 1770-73. 5 vols. 8vo, uniformly rebound in modern half morocco, in a black box . Portion of a larger work, partly printed earlier in Amsterdam (1766), printed without title. Very irregular pagination, probably incomplete. Vinograd, London 54, 55, 58; Roth, London 30, 31; Zedner 163; Jewish Enc. 3, p. 447 -- EDREHI, MOSES BEN ISAAC. Sefer Torat Chayyim [readings for Friday nights according to the custom of the Jews in Morocco]. London: Judah Leib ben Alexander, 1792. Title within simple typographical border. 8vo, modern blue morocco . Moses Gaster copy. Vinograd, London 135; Roth, London 65; Roth, Magna p. 338: 20; Zedner 451 -- EDREHI. Sefer Yad Mosheh [sermons]. Amsterdam: Widow and orphans Joseph Proops and Abraham ben Aaron Prins, 1809. Title within typographical border with crown and two cherubs. 4to, modern calf antique . Vinograd, Amsterdam 2380; Zedner 214; Cowley 464; Roest 321 -- BERDUGO, JACOB OF MEKNES. Kol Ya'akov [liturgical poems according to the Sephardic rite, a.o. in honor of M. Montefiore]. London, n.p., 1844. 8vo, modern buckram . Vinograd, London 418; Friedberg, kuf 363 -- LEVISOHN, MARCUS GEORGE (=Mordecai ben Judah Leib Gumpel). Ma'amar ha-Torah ve-ha-Chokhmah Chelek Rishon [scientific work]. London: Moses, Itzik and Jacob, 1771. 8vo, new artificial leather . Vinograd, London 63; Roth, London 22. -- MOSES BEN JUDAH OF MINSK. Even Shoham [exegetical work]. London: Moses ben Gershon, 1772. 8vo, modern cloth . Vinograd, London 69; Roth, London 28; Zedner 577 -- VAN OVEN, ABRAHAM. Derekh Ish Yashar The economy of human life, translated from an Indian manuscript, written by an ancient Bramin [...] with a translation into Hebrew. London: A. Alexander (=Alexander ben Judah Leib), 1778. 8vo, modern calf antique . Vinograd, London 97; Roth, London 44 -- PHINEHAS BEN SAMUEL. Sefer Midrash Pinchas [Talmudic exegesis]. London: David bar Mordechai Halevi, 1795. 8vo, 2 parts in one volume, modern cloth . Vinograd, London 142; Roth, London 75; Roth, Magna p. 339; Zedner 636 -- HART, JACOB (=Eliakim ben Abraham of London). Milchamot ha-Shem [polemical work] Binah le-Ittim [on secret chronology in the Book of Daniel]; Tsuf Novelot [kabbalistic commentary on Joseph Solomon Delmedigo's Novelot Chokhmah]. London: David bar Mordecai Halevi, 1794, 1795, 1799. 8vo, 3 parts in one volume, contemporary sheep, good condition . Vinograd, London 139, 143, 159; Roth, London 71; Zedner 219; Roest 352 -- BARONESS DESPENSER (=Lee, Rachel Fanny Antonia). Iggeret ha-Kolel el ha-Ivrim, or a circular epistle to the Hebrews [with a Hebrew translation by H.V. Bolaffey]. London: Naphtali Hirsh and his brother Mordecai ben Moses Eliezer, 1822. 8vo, disbound . Vinograd, London 243; Roth, London 123; Roth, Magna p. 230: 156; Cowley 125 -- HIRSCHEL, SOLOMON. Abstract of an Exhortation delivered by the Rev. Solomon Hirschel, at the Great Synagogue, [...] after a discourse on Jeremiah xi. 18, 19 [against sending Jewish children to Sunday schools and Free schools, in English and Yiddish]. [London]: E. Justins, 1807. 8vo, disbound . Vinograd, London 176; Roth, London 92; Roth, Magna 263: 43; Zedner 288; not in Cowley; not in Roest -- MELDOLA, DAVID. Kinah A Dirge in memory of the late much lamented Rev. Dr. [Raphael] Meldola, Chief Rabbi of the Spanish & Portuguese Jews' Congregation. [London]: n.p., 1828. 8vo, late 19th-century half cloth . Vinograd, London 278; Roth, London 138; Roth, Magna 342: 17. Raphael Meldola was Haham of the Sephardic Community in London. This dirge was composed by his son David -- KOHN-ZEDEK, JOSEPH. Sefer Musar Haskel Theological discourses delivered on various occasions; in Hebrew. London: Abrahams & son, 1878. 8vo, modern cloth . Cowley 379 -- ADLER, NATHAN MARCUS. [Silk imprint presented "To the Reverend NATHAN MARCUS ADLER, Chief Rabbi of the British Jews, on his first visit to the Maiden Lane Synagogue"]. London, 1846. Printed on silk, 380 x 255 mm., Hebrew and English, signed by the Wardens on behalf of the Committee and Congregation. (22)

ABRAVANEL, JUDAH. Dialogi de amore, composti per Leone Medico. Venice: Aldus, "in case de' figliuoli de Aldo", 1541. 8vo, contemporary Northern blind-tooled calf, rebacked and restored, X5 torn and repaired with partial loss of a few letters . Renouard, p. 123, no. 10. Contemporary ownership inscription of Francesco Scorsa; Andrew Fletcher of Saltoun's copy -- LUZZATTO, SIMONE. Discorso circa il stato de gl' Hebrei, et in particolar dimoranti nell'inclita Citta di Venetia. Venice: G. Calleoni, 1638. 4to, modern half calf, dampstained -- BELLARMINUS, ROBERTUS. [Hebrew] Institutiones linguae Hebraicae. Cologne, 1618 [ Bound with :] GASBAR MYRICAEUS, JOHANNES. [Syriac] Prima elementa linguae syricae Iesu-Christo vernaculo. Cologne, 1616. 8vo, 32 pp., contemporary goatskin, blind-tooled outer border enclosing central panel containing center gilt lozenge and gilt corner ornaments, spine gilt, worn, upper cover stained -- CARBONI, FRANCESCO. Flagellum Hebraeorum. Venice, 1672. 12mo, modern calf, uncut -- MEDICI, PAOLO. Riti, e costumi degli Ebrei. Venice, 1740. 8vo, modern half calf, uncut, some marginal dampstaining . (5)

ACKERMANN, RUDOLPH, publisher . Microcosm of London. [1808-10; plates watermarked up to 1836]. 3 vols., 4to, red half morocco gilt, t.e.g., other edges uncut, by Morrell, hinges and corners worn, lacks dedication leaves in vols. 2 and 3, most text and plates darkened, more heavily in vols. 1 and 2 than in vol. 3, offsetting to text and occasional offsetting to plates . Half-titles, wood engraved title pages and 104 colored aquatint plates by Bluck, Hill, Stadler and Sunderland after Thomas Rowlandson and A. Pugin. Abbey Scenery 212 ("The latest watermark known appears to be 1835"). (3)

ACKERMANN, RUDOLPH, publisher . A History of the University of Oxford. London: Ackermann, 1814 [plates watermarked 1812]. 2 vols., 4to, dark green morocco gilt, g.e., by Rogers of Bristol, plates offset to text, occasional faint offsetting on plates, portrait with some foxing . Engraved portrait of Lord Grenville, 114 colored plates including the 33 portraits of the Founders and the 17 costume plates; the views colored aquatints, the Founders in line and stipple with some aquatint, the costume plates in line and stipple, by Bennett, Bluck, Lewis, Meyer, Reeve and others after Nash, Pugin and others, 2 of Abbey's list of 8 plates (nos. 50 and 78) in first state, half-titles. Abbey Scenery 278 (large paper copy). (2)

ACKERMANN, RUDOLPH, publisher . A History of the University of Cambridge. London: Ackermann, 1815 [plates watermarked 1812, 1821, 1822 and 1834]. 2 vols., 4to, mid-nineteenth century purple hardgrained half morocco, spines gilt, t.e.g., marbled boards a little scuffed, extremities a trifle bumped, offsetting from plates to text, portrait foxed and facing dedication page browned . Engraved portrait of the Duke of Gloucester, 95 colored plates, including the 16 portraits of the Founders and the 15 costume plates; the views colored aquatints, the Founders and costume plates in line and stipple with aquatint in one instance, by Agar, Bluck, D. Havell, Stadler and others after Mackenzie, Pugin, Uwins and Westall, half-titles. Abbey Scenery 79 (large paper copy). Bookplates of Ferdinand M. McVeagh. Colored views are bright and clean. (2)

ACKERMANN, RUDOLPH, publisher . The History of the Colleges. London: Ackermann, 1816 [plates watermarked 1812]. 4to, royal blue half morocco gilt, t.e.g. by Bayntun, some old marginal dampstaining throughout, now carefully cleaned but the paper of text and plates sometimes softened and faintly discolored at outer and lower portions in the margins, some text spotted . 48 colored plates, including the 4 costume plates, the views colored aquatints, the costume plates in line and stipple, by Agar, Bluck, D. Havell, Stadler and others after Mackenzie, Pugin, Westall and others, Abbey's first state of plate 23 (the masters bareheaded) and second state of plate 26 (with washerwomen and with caption overslip). Abbey Scenery 440.

ACOSTA, ISAAC DE. Conjeturas sagradas sobre los prophetas primeros. Leyden [Bayonne?]: Thomas van Ge'el, 5482 [1722]. 4to, modern half calf gilt; minor staining . Wolf, III, 1169b, IV, 18; Rodr.Castro, 506; Kayserling, 8; Palau, 1973; Den Boer, Catalogue [...] Ets Haim/Livraria Montezinos , n. 12.

ADDISON, LANCELOT. THE PRESENT STATE OF THE JEWS: (MORE PARTICULARLY RELATING TO THOSE IN BARBARY.). 1675. NEW CALF, A LITTLE MARGINAL DAMPSTAINING . FIRST EDITION, engraved frontispiece. Wing A-526; Roth, p. 394 (B18, no. 22). Some copious contemporary ink annotation -- OCKLEY, SIMON. The History of the Present Jews. 1711. 12mo, new calf, browned -- [MEARS, ABRAHAM]. The Book of Religion, Ceremonies, and Prayers; of the Jews. 1738. Contemporary calf, rebacked, slight worming at end . Roth, p. 302 (B8, no. 6) -- LOWMAN, MOSES. A Dissertation on the Civil Government of the Hebrews. 1740. New half calf . FIRST EDITION -- Second edition of the preceding. Contemporary calf gilt, joints cracked -- LOWMAN, M. A Rational of the Ritual of Hebrew Worship. 1816. Contemporary calf gilt . See Roth, p. 353 (B14, no. 65) for an earlier edition -- [ALEXANDER, LEVY]. Alexander's Hebrew Ritual. 1819. New rexine, lacks title . Roth, p. 333 (B11, no. 25) -- ADAMS, HANNAH. The History of the Jews. 1818. New cloth, uncut . Roth, p. 347 (B14, no. 91) -- PAYBA, ABRAHAM. The Memorial presented to the High Court of La Tournelle at Paris in favour of Abraham Payba, Jew, a native of London; against E[dwar]d W[ortle]y M[ontag]u, Esq., and T[heobal]d T[aaff]e, Esq. 1752. New calf . Roth, p. 251 (B3, no. 19). All London, 8vo . (9)

ADRICHOM, CHRISTIAAN VAN. Theatrum Terrae Sanctae et Biblicarum Historiarum cum tabulis geographicis cere expressis. Cologne: Officina Birckmannica, 1590. Folio, Italian 18th-century vellum over pasteboard, covers bowed; most text browned, title-leaf patched in three places, affecting engraved border in two of them, folding maps of Holy Land and Jerusalem with repairs, Ephraim, Beniamin and Dan map cropped at bottom edge, Manasse map cropped at right margin, the double-page maps with offsetting (not severe), Bb3 with small repaired tear . First Edition in Latin, engraved title and 12 engraved maps. Rhricht 791; Tobler, p. 210; Laor T-18; Nordenskiold Collection 1.

ALMOSNINO, MOSES BEN BARUCH. Regimiento de la vida. Amsterdam: [N.p.]. 5489 [1729]. 4to, contemporary vellum, old repair to upper cover, some staining; minor dampstaining . Kayserling, 11; Palau, 8207; Den Boer, Catalogue [...] Ets Haim/Livraria Montezinos, n. 18.
